editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

I but when the Lord Je≈øus Chri≈øt comes unto a Duty, and ≈øets his own ≈øtamp, and his own righteou≈øne≈øs upon a Duty, that which was bra≈ø≈øe before; full of failings, and much unrighteou≈øne≈øs before, changes it into gold, into ≈øilver. He only hath the Philo≈øophers ≈øtone (as I may ≈øo ≈øpeak) all that Chri≈øt touches turns into gold; turns all our Duties into gold: and when he hath done ≈øo, he pre≈øents them unto God the Father. This our great High-Prie≈øt doth. And this is the Fourth thing.

p.hi: But how doth all this make for our Comfort,
p.label: Que≈øt. 5
p.hi: or for our Grace?

div.p: Surely, An≈ø. we cannot but ≈øee already how it doth make for our Comfort:

Is it not a comfortable thing, for a man to know, that his Duties are not lo≈øt? that his Prayer is not lo≈øt? that his Hearing the word is not lo≈øt? that his Searching the Scriptures is not lo≈øt? that his Conference, and Communion is not lo≈øt? A man is unwilling to lo≈øe any thing: and the more precious it is, the more unwilling to lo≈øe it. If we have a venture at Sea; we are unwilling to lo≈øe our venture: and the greater our venture is, the more unwilling to lo≈øe it. If a man have but a quarter of his E≈øtate in a ve≈ø≈øel, he is unwilling to lo≈øe it; more unwilling if he have half his E≈øtate; mo≈øt if he have all, and his children there in the ve≈ø≈øel too. Now as men are unwilling to lo≈øe their worldly venture: So, a man that is ≈øen≈øible of his ≈øoul, is very unwilling to lo≈øe his ≈øouls venture; to lo≈øe his Prayers, and to lo≈øe all his Duties. (Friends) here's an In≈øuring-Office; The Lord Je≈øus Chri≈øt is our great In≈øurer in this re≈øpect: and he doth as he is our High-Prie≈øt, offering up our Gifts unto God the Father, a≈ø≈øure us that none is lo≈øt, not any lo≈øt. Indeed, if we had ≈øuch an High-Prie≈øt, as were not able to take notice of the Circum≈øtances of our Duties, much might be lo≈øt: but, this our Lord Chri≈øt, our great High-Prie≈øt, doth not only take notice of our Duty what ever it be; but of all the Circum≈øtances of our Duties, and ≈øo pre≈øents them unto God the Father, in the full latitude, in all the gracious Circum≈øtances of them. Therefore ≈øaith he, unto the Angel of the Church of Pergamos in the 2. of the Revelation, and the 13. ver≈øe; I know thy works. Why, but Lord, though thou doe≈øt know our works, yet it may be thou doe≈øt not take notice where our work is done: Lord, it may be thou doe≈øt take notice of my Prayer, but Lord, thou doe≈øt not take notice where I dwell, and live, and in what family I do pray unto thee; Lord, I am in a wicked, and a wretched family, that does oppo≈øe Prayer: Lord, may be thou doe≈øt take notice of my Prayer, but thou doe≈øt not take notice, of this Circum≈øtance: Yes, (≈øaies he) I know thy works, and where thou dwelle≈øt, even where Satans ≈øeat is. Well, and thou holde≈øt fa≈øt my Name, and ha≈øt
not denied my faith, even in tho≈øe daies wherein Antipas was my faithful martyr, who was ≈ølain among you, where Satan dwelleth. It's remarkable, The Lord Je≈øus Chri≈øt takes notice, not only of our Duty; but of every Circum≈øtance of the Duty, and ≈øo he pre≈øents it unto God the Father, not only the Duty, but the Circum≈øtance of the Duty; and therefore there is not a haire of your Duty lo≈øt, not one graine of your Duty lo≈øt: is not this an un≈øpeakable Comfort unto a poor ≈øoul, that it knows that nothing is lo≈øt of all the Prayers it hath made unto God, that there is no lo≈ø≈øe at all? The very pantings of our hearts at the Throne of grace, are received into the bo≈øom of our Heavenly Father.

Further, Is it not a Comfort for a man to have liberty to go unto the Mercy-Seat, and there for to meet with God? 'Tis ≈øaid of wicked men, That they ≈øit in the ≈øeat of the ≈øcornful. There is, (it ≈øeems then) the ≈øeat of the ≈øcornful; and there is a Mercy-Seat: A Drunkard, when he is with his drunken company, and ≈øits upon the Ale-bench (it may be) ≈øcorning, and jeering at ≈øome of the godly, making ≈øongs on them, he is ≈øet upon the ≈øeat of the ≈øcornful; that is a cur≈øed ≈øeat. I but, there is another ≈øeat, there is a Mercy-Seat; and there is never a poor Saint and Child of God, but he may go in to the Mercy-Seat of the Lord Je≈øus Chri≈øt that hath all the favour, and acceptance in Heaven; he carries him into the Mercy-Seat, and God the Father will never put him by; what Comfort is here!

Be≈øides, Is it not a great Comfort to a man, for to know how it ≈øhall go with him at the great day of Judgment? When there ≈øhall be hundred thou≈øands at the right hand of Chri≈øt; & hundred-thou≈øands at the left hand of Chri≈øt; when all faces ≈øhall gather palene≈ø≈øe? Oh! (≈øaies one) that I did but know, how it ≈øhall go with me at that day! This Doctrine tels us, The Lord Je≈øus Chri≈øt ≈øhall be our Judge at that day, and he that ≈øhall judge us then, he takes our Prayers and all our Duties now, and carries them in unto the pre≈øence of God the Father, & by him we have
acceptance, and according to the≈øe we ≈øhall be judged. Surely then, if he takes our Duties and carries them in for acceptance, unto God the Father, he will never judge you for them, and condemn you for them at that day. Here is Comfort!

Once more, Is it not a Comfort, for a poor begger to be relieved at a rich-mans door? We are al beggers in regard of Heaven; and the Lord Je≈øus Chri≈øt, he does not only come forth and ≈øerve us, but he takes us (poor beggers) by the hand, and leads us in to his Father. Oh! what Comfort is here! what Comfort is here!

p.hi: Indeed if I were able to ≈øay, That the Lord did accept my Duty,

this were Comfort indeed; if I were able to conclude, That the Lord Je≈øus Chri≈øt did take my Prayers, and my Duties, and carry them in unto God the Father; this were ≈øweet con≈øolation: but how ≈øhall I know that?

div.p: If the Lord Je≈øus Chri≈øt be our High-Prie≈øt, An≈ø. then we may ≈øay al≈øo, that he takes our duties, and carries them in for acceptance unto God the Father: if we may ≈øay that Je≈øus Chri≈øt hath ≈øatisfied for us, and doth intercede for us, then we may ≈øay al≈øo, that he takes our duties, and carries them for acceptance unto God the Father.
But yet a little further, to bring this Comfort nearer to your hearts; give me leave to appeal to you:

Fir≈øt. Who≈øoever thou art that makes this Objection: Did≈øt thou never find a ≈øpiritual fire come down from Heaven (as it were) upon thy heart in Duty, or after Duty? In the times of the old-Te≈øtament, if they offered up a ≈øacrifice, and a material fire came down from Heaven and burnt up the ≈øacrifice to a≈øhes, it was a certain te≈øtimony, that the ≈øacrifice was accepted. Now in the times of the Go≈øpel we mu≈øt not expect material fire to come down upon our Duties: But hath the Lord at any time cau≈øed an inward, and ≈øpiritual fire to fall down upon thy heart, warming thy ≈øpirit in Dutie? there the Lord ≈øpeaks thus much to thee; Thy ≈øacrifice is turn'd into a≈øhes, and it is accepted by Je≈øus Chri≈øt.

Again, Did you never find in your heart (you that make this Objection) to Pray, and Cry, and Intercede for others, for the godly e≈øpecially? Look what di≈øpo≈øition there is in your heart towards the members of Chri≈øt, there is the ≈øame di≈øpo≈øition in Chri≈øt's heart towards you. Ah! do you think that there is love in your bo≈øome towards the Saints; and that there is none in Chri≈øt's heart towards you? Do you think that your bowels are more large than Chri≈øt's? Can≈øt thou find in thine heart to go unto God, when thou ≈øee≈øt a Saint in mi≈øery, to go to God, and pray, and cry, and intercede for him? and don't you think that the Lord Je≈øus hath as much bowels towards you, to go and intercede for you, and pre≈øent your prayers unto God the Father.

Further, Don't you look upon your own Duties, as coming from your ≈øelves, mo≈øt unworthy? Beloved! 'tis in regard of Duties, as it is in regard of Per≈øons: When a man does judge him≈øelf to be mo≈øt unworthy, then Chri≈øt counts him worthy, God counts him worthy in Chri≈øt. As you reade in the 1. of the Canticles, ≈øaies the Spou≈øe there, ver. 5. I am black (O ye daughters of Jeru≈øalem) as the tents of Kedar: Look not upon me becau≈øe I am black, ver. 6. Now would you ≈øee Chri≈øts opinion of her, that counts her ≈øelf black? ≈øaith ≈øhe, Black, and Black again: but Chri≈øt ≈øaith concerning her; ver≈øe, 8. O thou faire≈øt among women. She calls her ≈øelf Black, and Chri≈øt cals her Fair, and the Faire≈øt among women. Now, when a man doth count him≈øelf mo≈øt unworthy, God counts him mo≈øt worthy: and when a man looks upon his own Duties, and Sacrifices, as mo≈øt unworthy, they are look't upon by Je≈øus Chri≈øt as mo≈øt worthy, poor prayers in our eyes, are precious in Gods eye.

A word more, Don't ye think, that grace is larger now, in the times of the Go≈øpel, than it was in the times of the Law? If ye doubt it, as unto this particular; Look upon the 30. Chapter of Exodus; compared with the 41. of Ezekiel. In the 30. Chapter of Exodus, The Lord commands an Altar to be made to burn incen≈øe upon; Of Shittim wood
≈øhalt thou make it; ver≈øe the 1. A cubit ≈øhall be the length thereof, ver≈øe the 2. The Altar is for Incen≈øe; 'tis the matter that now we are upon: A cubit ≈øhall be the length thereof, and a cubit the breadth thereof, and two cubits ≈øhall be the highth therof. Now in the 41. Chapter of Ezekiel, he ≈øpeaks of the Altar in the times of the Go≈øpel: and (≈øaith he) at the 22. ver≈øe, ('tis the Altar of incen≈øe that there is pre≈øcribed to be made, the Altar of wood, of Shettem wood.) The Altar of wood was three cubits high, and the length thereof two cubits. And yet again, this altar of incen≈øe in the times of the Go≈øpel, is to be as large again, as that in the times of the Law; as high, and as long, and as large again. In the times of the Law, times of the old-Te≈øtament; a poor ≈øoul might go unto the High-Prie≈øt, and might challenge a right in him, and might ≈øay, That his Service, and his Duty, and his Sacrifice was accepted by the High-Prie≈øt. If in the times of the Old-Te≈øtament a man might ≈øay ≈øo; much more may a poor ≈øoul now go unto Je≈øus Chri≈øt, our great High-Prie≈øt, and ≈øay, That his Service, and his Duty, and Sacrifice, is accepted through him. Here is abundance of Comfort unto the Saints: be of good comfort, all you that do beleeve.

But, How doth this make unto our Holine≈øs,
Que≈øt.
unto Holine≈øs of life? We confe≈øs indeed, that there is abundance of Comfort in this, That the Lord Je≈øus Chri≈øt, our great High-Prie≈øt, takes all our Gifts, and al our Prayers, and pre≈øents them to God the Father, and that in his acceptance, we have acceptance: but I pray, how doth all this conduce to our Holine≈øs of life?
Much every way: An≈øw.

Fir≈øt, In ca≈øe I be Ungodly, a Wicked man: Here is that that may for ever keep me, from oppo≈øition to the good wayes of God. I have ≈øaid ≈øometimes (may a wicked man ≈øay) concerning godly mens duties, That it was their Hypocri≈øie: And I have ≈øaid concerning ≈øuch and ≈øuch Profe≈ø≈øors, This is your Pride, and this is your Singularity; and I have oppo≈øed with all bitterne≈øs, and earne≈øtne≈øs, the prayings, and wre≈øtlings of ≈øome of Gods people? But is
this true, That the Lord Je≈øus Chri≈øt, takes every Prayer, of the meane≈øt of Gods Children, and carries it into the bo≈øom of God the Father? and ≈øhall I ≈øpit upon that that Chri≈øt owns? ≈øhall I dare to oppo≈øe that that the Lord Je≈øus Chri≈øt pre≈øents unto his Father? The Lord in mercy pardon me: I have ≈øinned and done fooli≈øhly, and for ought I know, I may have ≈øpoken evill of that Duty, that Chri≈øt hath carried into the pre≈øence of God the Father: Oh! through the Lords grace then, for ever will I leave to make any oppo≈øition, again≈øt any of the good waies of God again, and I will never ≈øpeake one word again≈øt the per≈øons, meetings, or ≈øupplications of the godly again.

Again, In ca≈øe a man be Ungodly, a wicked man: Here is mighty incouragement, for to come unto Je≈øus Chri≈øt; I, and to come pre≈øently. For, is Je≈øus Chri≈øt the ladder that Jacob ≈øaw, by whom we go up to Heaven? doth he take all our Duties, and Prayers, and pre≈øent them to God the Father for acceptance? Then, till I do come to Chri≈øt, all is nothing, all is lo≈øt: if I be a Drunkard, and will not come to Chri≈øt, Prayer is all lo≈øt; if I be a Swearer, and will not come to Chri≈øt, an Unclean wretch, and will not come to Chri≈øt; all my Prayers, and all my Duties are lo≈øt: Oh! the Lord pity me, (may many a poor ≈øoul ≈øay) I have lo≈øt too many Prayers already; through the Lords grace, now I will lo≈øe no more: Oh! I come to Chri≈øt, Lord, I come, I come. This is a mighty incouragement, to make every man now for to come unto Je≈øus Chri≈øt: becau≈øe the Lord Je≈øus, our High-Prie≈øt, takes every Duty; and carries it into the bo≈øom. of God the Father for acceptance. Thus for Ungodly.
Secondly, In ca≈øe a man be Godly; this truth doth conduce to our further Holine≈øs, and growth in grace.

If I be Codly: Then here I ≈øee infinite rea≈øon, why I ≈øhould be much in Duty; not only pray, but be much in prayer. Why? for the Lord Chri≈øt taketh all, and carries all into the bo≈øom of the Father, mingles his own odours,
interce≈ø≈øions with it, although it be but a ≈øigh, and a groane. The Apo≈øtle upon this account, makes this u≈øe of it; having ≈øpoken of Chri≈øt our High-Prie≈øt; Therefore (≈øaith he) let us come with boldne≈øs vnto the Throne of grace.
Heb. 4.16 The word ≈øignifies, to ≈øpeak all ones mind; let us come ≈øpeaking all. Having ≈øuch an High-Prie≈øt indeed, as will carry all into the pre≈øence of God the Father, for acceptance, every ≈øigh, and every groan; then, who would not be much in prayer? ≈øpeak all to Chri≈øt, be free with Chri≈øt, come with boldne≈øs? There's many a poor ≈øoul, that is much di≈øcouraged, and he dares not go to prayer, many times, afraid to go to the Throne of grace. The rea≈øon is, becau≈øe he looks upon his Prayer, or Duty, as it lies upon his own heart, or as it comes from him≈øelf. Whereas, my beloved, 'tis with your Prayers, and Duties, as it is with fire: Your kitchin fire is troubled with abundance of ≈ømoake, and there is filth about it; fire upon the hearth hath much ≈ømoake: but fire above, in the Element of fire, there's no ≈ømoke. So, your Prayer, when it lies upon your own hearth (as I may ≈øay) there's a great deal of ≈ømoke; but when it gets once into the hands of Je≈øus Chri≈øt, there's it's Element, and it is freed from all it's ≈ømoke. Or as it is with a mans Body: ≈øo long as he lives here upon the earth, he is feeble, and weak, and many times ≈øickly: a≈ø≈øoon as he is come into Heaven, all his weakne≈øs is taken away, and his body being in Heaven, 'tis pre≈øently glorified, and ≈øtrength put upon it, and all his di≈øea≈øes are gone. So 'tis with our Prayers: So long as they are here below, in our own bo≈øoms, they are full of weakne≈øs; but a≈ø≈øoon as our Prayer is out of our mouth, 'tis in the hand of Chri≈øt, 'tis in Heaven, 'tis glorified, the weakne≈øs is now done away; Oh! 'tis a glorified Prayer; when once 'tis gone from you, 'tis in the hand of Chri≈øt. And therefore, this is a mighty incouragement unto all tho≈øe that are godly, to be, not only in Prayer, but to be much in Prayer, come with boldne≈øs unto the Throne of grace.

Again, If ye be Godly; yea, if ye be Ungodly: Here I
≈øee infinite rea≈øon, why I ≈øhould receive every Truth that comes from Chri≈øt, though accompanied with many failings in him that ≈øpeaks it. The Lord Je≈øus Chri≈øt, he accepts of every prayer, and duty that comes from me; though it have many weakne≈ø≈øes: yea, he takes my Prayer, and carries it into the pre≈øence of God the Father for acceptance, my poor Prayer, labouring with many weakne≈ø≈øes: Then when a Truth comes from Chri≈øt, ≈øhall not I accept of it? what though the Mini≈øter, or Preacher that ≈øpeaks it, labour with this or that weakne≈øs? There is Pride, or there is ≈øome mi≈øcarriage in the delivery, or the like: Shall the Lord Chri≈øt take my Prayer, labouring under infirmity, and accept thereof, and carry it into the pre≈øence of God the Father for acceptance, notwith≈øtanding all the failings of my Duty? and ≈øhall not I accept of Truth that comes from Chri≈øt, notwith≈øtanding all the failings of the poor me≈ø≈øenger that brings it?

Further, The more Evangelical you are in your Obedience, the more Holy ye are in your lives. This truth that is now before ye, well ≈øtudied and con≈øidered, will make you more Obedient in an Evangelical way. And ye ≈øhall find therefore, that the Lord him≈øelf from Heaven does make this u≈øe of it: pray con≈øult with the 17. of Matthew, and the 5. ver≈øe. This is my beloved Son in whom I am well plea≈øed: hear ye him. Tho≈øe words follow, Hear him. Hearing notes Faith, and Obedience; not a bare Hearing with the ear. Compare this, and the ≈øame ≈øpeech together, which ye have in the 3. of Matthew, and the 17. ver≈øe. Loe, a voyce from Heaven, ≈øaying, This is my beloved Son in whom I am well plea≈øed. Heare ye him, is not there in the 3. of Matthew; but here in the 17. of Matthew, the≈øe words are added, Heare ye him: What ≈øhould the rea≈øon be, that, Hear ye him, ≈øhould be added here in the 17. of Matthew, and not in the 3. of Mat. thew? Give me leave to give you ≈øome rea≈øon for it, ≈øo far as may make to our pre≈øent purpo≈øe: Not to ≈øay any thing of that which Mo≈øes ≈øaid, In his daies a Prophet will the Lord your God rai≈øe up unto ye like unto me, hear ye him.
And now here, in this 17. of Matthew, at the transfiguration, Mo≈øes and Elias appeared, which they did not in the 3. of Matthew.

Fir≈øt, Con≈øider, that the Empha≈øis may lie upon the word Hear, and not upon the word Him, only: This is my beloved Son in whom I am well plea≈øed: Hear ye him; His face did ≈øhine as the Sun, and his rayment was white as the light. And Chri≈øt appeared in great glory, and they ≈øtood looking upon him; Nay, (≈øaies the Lord from Heaven) do not make it a gazing matter, but, Hear him: don't ≈øtand looking upon him, but Hear him. He don't appear in ≈øuch a glory in the 3. of Matthew, when he was baptized; and therefore tho≈øe words are not added there.

But again, Here now in the 17. Chapter of Matthew, at the Transfiguration, appears Mo≈øes, and Elias. Behold (at the 3. ver≈øe) There appeared unto them, Mo≈øes and Elias talking with him. Mo≈øes that gave the Law; Elias that re≈øtored it. Then an≈øwered Peter and ≈øaid unto Je≈øus; Lord, 'tis good for us to be here: if thou wilt, let us make here Three Tabernacles; one for Thee, and one for Mo≈øes and one for Elias. Peter and ≈øo the re≈øt of the Di≈øciples, began for to equallize Mo≈øes to Je≈øus Chri≈øt: One for Mo≈øes, and one for Elias, and one for Je≈øus Chri≈øt; no more for Chri≈øt than for Mo≈øes. Now the Lord takes Peter off from all his mi≈øtakings: Your eye is upon Mo≈øes (≈øaith he) but I (≈øaith the Lord God Almighty) am wel plea≈øed in my Son: This is my beloved Son in whom I am well plea≈øed. I am well plea≈øed with you, and with your Duties, through this my Son, and not through Mo≈øes; and therefore Hear Chri≈øt, and not Mo≈øes. He laies this in upon it, that therefore they ≈øhould be Evangelical, and hear Je≈øus Chri≈øt, becau≈øe the Lord Chri≈øt gives acceptance unto all, and by him God is well plea≈øed with them.

Again further, The more glory Chri≈øt does appear in,
the greater rea≈øon there is why we ≈øhould hear him. Now here the Lord Je≈øus Chri≈øt appeared in glory; his face did ≈øhine as the Sun, and his raiment was white as the light. In the 3.
of Matthew, he was there baptized, and he did not appear in glory: but now here he appears in glory; and therefore ≈øaies the Lord, now Hear him; this is your glorious Saviour, Hear him. Beloved! what greater glory can Je≈øus Chri≈øt appear to your ≈øouls in, than this, the glory of his love? he takes every one of your Duties, and your Prayers, and he carries them in to the bo≈øome of God the Father, and by him you have acceptance. Oh! what a glorious Saviour have ye! therefore Hear him: This is that, if any thing, will make ye very Obedient to Chri≈øt, more than to Mo≈øes, to be Evangelical in all your Duties.

Yet further, The more a man can rejoyce in ≈øpiritual priviledges with humility: and the more humble a man is, and yet can rejoyce in his ≈øpiritual priviledges, the more holy he is: there goes a great deal of Holine≈øs to it, to joyn the≈øe two together: for a man to rejoyce in his ≈øpiritual priviledges and yet to be humble: and to walk very humbly. Some there are, that look upon ther ≈øpiritual priviledges, and rejoyce much; but they don't walk humbly: Some labour to walk humbly, and are much troubled in the con≈øideration of their own evil; but they don't rejoyce in their ≈øpiritual priviledges. Give me a Chri≈øtian that doth both, and he is a ble≈ø≈øed man. The ≈øtudy of this Truth that is now before you, will teach you to do both, to do both together For, what a great priviledge is this, not a figh, not a groane, not a duty, but the Lord Chri≈øt takes it, and carries it in, and pre≈øents it to God the Father for me, whereby I have acceptance? Con≈øidering this; here is matter of much joy and rejoycing. I but, It is Chri≈øt that does it; there is no ≈øuch worthine≈øs in mine own duty; it were lo≈øt, and ca≈øt away, if Je≈øus Chri≈øt did not take it in his hand, and carry it into the bo≈øome of God the Father; and therefore, why ≈øhould I not walk humbly.

I conclude all with this, If that the Lord Je≈øus Chri≈øt, our great High-Prie≈øt, offers up all our Gifts unto God the Father, whereby we have acceptance: What infinite
cau≈øe have we all to be Thankful to God for Chri≈øt, and to love Je≈øus Chri≈øt for ever!

Suppo≈øe one of you had been among the Di≈øciples, when the Lord Chri≈øt wa≈øh't his Di≈øciples feet; and he ≈øhould have come, and wa≈øh't your feet, and have done it; would not your heart have glowed with love to Je≈øus Chri≈øt? div.head: SATANS Power to tempt; AND CHRISTS love to, and care of his people under temptation.

epigraph.q: For in that He him≈øelf hath ≈øuffered being tempted, Preached at Margrets New-fi≈øh ≈øtreet Octob. 5. 1646. he is able to ≈øuccour them that are tempted.

div.p:
THE Scope and Drift of this Epi≈øtle, is to rai≈øe and ≈øtrengthen the faith of the Hebrewes, and ≈øo the faith of tho≈øe that are weak in grace. Our Apo≈øtle Paul therefore (whom I take to be the Pen-man) labours to di≈øcover the tran≈øcendent Excellency of Je≈øus Chri≈øt, with his love and good-will to the Children of men. And becau≈øe his Excellencies, were either ≈øuch as relate his Per≈øon; or ≈øuch as relate his Offices, of King, Prie≈øt, & Prophet: He tels us in the
fir≈øt Chapter, that for the Per≈øonal Excellencies of Je≈øus Chri≈øt; He is the Son of God; Heire of all things; by whom were the Worlds made: being the brightne≈øs of his Fathers glory, and the expre≈øs Image of his Per≈øon, in the 2, & 3. ver≈øes of that Chapters. That he is far above the Angels, at the 4. ver≈øe. That he is God him≈øelf, at the 6. ver≈øe. And as for tho≈øe excellencies that relate his Offices: He tels us at the 1. ver≈øe, That he is the Prophet of Prophets. That he is the great King, at the 8. ver≈øe. That he is an High-Prie≈øt, in the 2. Chap. and the 17. ver≈øe: and therefore who would not tru≈øt unto him, and take heed unto ≈øuch things are he ≈øhall ≈øpeak unto them. And as for the love, and good-will that he bears unto the Children of men; the Apo≈øtle ≈øpeaks it out in all this Second Chapter.

The greater Conde≈øeention in the per≈øon loving, to the per≈øon loved, the greater is the love. Now though Je≈øus Chri≈øt be Heir of all things; and had all things put under his feet; far above all Angels: yet notwith≈øtanding, at the 7. ver≈øe, He is made a little lower than the Angels, takes our nature upon him, &c.

The more Profitable any love is, to the per≈øon loved, the greater is the love. Such is the love of Chri≈øt; for his love is ≈øuch, That by him many ≈øons are brought to glory, at the 10. ver≈øe. Sanctified while they live, at the 11. ver≈øe. Satan their deadly enemy ≈øubdued for them, at the 14, & 15: ver≈øes.

The more Di≈øtingui≈øhing any love is, the greater is that love. Now Je≈øus Chri≈øt, as the great Load-≈øtone, pa≈ø≈øes by the golden mettel of Angels, and draws unto him≈øelf the Iron-mettal of man kind, at the 16. ver≈øe: For verily, he took not on him the nature of Angels; but he took on him the ≈øeed of Abraham.

Again, The more the per≈øon loving, does Suffer for the per≈øon loved, the more and the greater is the love. Chri≈øt ≈øuffered death, and he was while he lived ≈øubject to our infirmities, and unto our temptations: He was in all thing made like unto us, at the 17. ver≈øe. And he was tempted as we are tempted, that he might ≈øuccour tho≈øe that are tempted, at the 18. ver≈øe.

And would you have an Account, or a Rea≈øon of all this? it is, that he might ≈øhew mercy unto the children of men, ver≈øe the 17. Wherefore in all things it behoved him to be made like unto his brethren, that he might be a merciful and faithful High-Prie≈øt, in things partaining to God, to make reconciliation for the ≈øins of the people. If he were not made like unto us in regard of our infirmities, he could not ≈øo experimentally pity us under our infirmities: If he were not tempted like unto us, he could not ≈øo feelingly ≈øuccour us under our temptation; and ≈øo he had not been ≈øo fit to have benn our High-Prie≈øt: but our High-Prie≈øt he is gone into the holy of holie≈øt, to make reconciliation for the ≈øins of the people. Wherefore in all things it behoved him to be made like unto us, that he might be a merciful and faithful High-Prie≈øt: For in that he him≈øelf hath ≈øuffered being tempted, be is able to ≈øuccour them that are tempted,

I will not hold you longer in the Coherence, or Divi≈øion of the words, or further Explication: I ≈øhall open the words (God willing) more particularly, and di≈øtinctly, as I ≈øhall come to the Ob≈øervations that ≈øhall be rai≈øed from them. And I begin with the la≈øt, being made the rea≈øon of the former. For in that he him ≈øelf hath ≈øuffered being tempted, he is able to ≈øuccour them that are tempted. Tempted twice: He tempted, and They tempted.

This word Tempted, or Tempt; it is given in Scripture phra≈øe, ≈øometimes to God, ≈øometimes to Man, and ≈øometimes to the Devil; and accordingly it is u≈øed Three waies: Sometimes it is u≈øed for to Prove; and ≈øo God is ≈øaid for to Tempt, in the 13. of Deuteronomy. Sometimes it is u≈øed for to Try, to make experiment of a Thing, or a Per≈øon, whom or which we did not know before; and ≈øo it is given to Man (as I take it) in the 6. of Judges. Sometimes it is u≈øed for a Solicitation, and Drawing unto what is evil; and ≈øo it is given unto the Devil, in the 4. of Matthew, Chri≈øt was led into the axilderne≈øs to be tempted. If ye look into the Scripture, ye don't find in all the old Te≈øtament, that the word Temptation is given to Satan, that Satan was ≈øaid to Tempt any:
Satan did frequently Tempt, we reade in the old Te≈øtament; but I ≈øay, the word Tempt is not given unto him. Satan tempted Job, but Job's afflictions in the old Te≈øtament, are not called Satans temptations. As our Lord and Saviour Chri≈øt in the old Te≈øtament was Vail'd, the old Te≈øtament was full of Chri≈øt, yet Chri≈øt was hidden there: So was Satan and his temptations mask't. Now when the light of the glorious Go≈øpel ≈øhined more cleerly in the comming of Je≈øus Chri≈øt, as Chri≈øts vail was taken off, ≈øo Satans Mask was taken off; Satans temptations are no longer called afflictions, but bare Temptations, throughout the new-Te≈øtament. Indeed, this word Temptation, in the phra≈øe of the new Te≈øtament, is u≈øed ≈øometimes for Affliction; Sometimes for Satans Sugge≈øtions; ≈øometimes for our own Sins. Temptation u≈øed for our Afflictions: in the 1. of James, 2. ver≈øe, Rejoyce when ye fall into divers temptations. That is, Afflictions. Sometimes for the Devils ≈øugge≈øtions, Solicitations to evil. So in the 4. of Matthew, Chri≈øt is led into the wilderne≈øs to be tempted. Sometimes for our own ≈øins. Galatians the 6 chapter, and the 1. ver≈øe. If any man be overtaken with an infirmity, you that are ≈øpiritual, re≈øtore him, con≈øidering that you al≈øo may be tempted. Now though our Saviour Chri≈øt is ≈øaid to be Tempted, in the two fir≈øt re≈øpects, and not in the third; yet when it is ≈øaid here in the text, He him≈øelf hath ≈øuffered being tempted; I take it to be meant in the ≈øecond way, not the fir≈øt: for otherwi≈øe, there would be an identity thus: He him≈øelf hath ≈øuffered; having ≈øuffered; that would be the ≈øen≈øe of it el≈øe. And though we our ≈øelves are ≈øaid to be tempted in all three re≈øpects, In regard of Afflictions, Satans Sugge≈øtions, and our own Corruptions, and Sins; yet when it is ≈øaid in the latter end of the ver≈øe, He is able to ≈øuccour them that are tempted; I take it to be meant e≈øpecially in he two la≈øt re≈øpects, and not in the fir≈øt: for it hath relation unto that which goes before the la≈øt ver≈øe being a rea≈øon of the latter end of the 17. ver≈ø. To make reconciliation for the ≈øins of the people, for in that he him≈øelf hath ≈øuffered, being tempted, he is able to ≈øuccovr them that
are tempted. Hence the Ob≈øervation that I ≈øhall pre≈øent unto you is only this.

div.p: Our Lord and Saviour Chri≈øt, the Son of God, the only Beloved Son of God, yet ≈øaith the text, He him≈øelf hath ≈øuffered being tempted: not only tempted, but ≈øuffered being tempted. For the opening, and clearing of this Truth, I ≈øhall deliver my ≈øelf the≈øe Three waies.

Fir≈øt, There is a Vexing, Corroding,
Afflictive di≈øpo≈øition in every temptation, when it takes lea≈øt, though it do not prevaile The≈øe Granadoes, fire-bals, fire-darts of Satan have a danger with them; though they do not burn down our ≈øpiritual building to the ground, they are afflictive, there is ≈øomewhat of a ≈øuffering with them. Notable is that expre≈ø≈øion which our Saviour Chri≈øt u≈øeth, in the 22. of Luke, at the 31. ver≈øe, to Peter. Simon, Simon, Satan hath de≈øired to have you, that he may ≈øift you as wheat. There is never a word here, but carries a ≈øuffering with it. But in other Authors that u≈øe it, it ≈øignifies ≈øuch a De≈øiring, as when one man does challenge another into the field to a Duel: Or ≈øuch a De≈øiring, as when a man comes and cals for open, and publick Puni≈øhment upon a man: and all this is Suffering, and Afflictive. Or, as your tran≈ølation hath it: Satan hath de≈øired to Have you. He does not ≈øay thus: Satan hath de≈øired to Sift you; but Satan hath de≈øired to Have you. Is it not an affliction to a child, to hear a Begger ≈øtand craving, and begging of his father to have him away, to carry him away from his hou≈øe? Then again, He hath de≈øired to have you that he may [≈øift you as wheat.] Now though in ≈øifting, there is a ≈øeparation between the Chaff and the wheat, yet it is not without a concu≈ø≈øion, and a ≈øhaking of the wheat: the wheat and the grain is ≈øhaken, though the chaffe be blown a≈øide, and laid on heaps. And though through the skil of the ≈øifter, the wheat may be ≈øo kept, as it does not fal into the chaffe-heap; yet notwith≈øtanding, there is ≈øome danger in ≈øifting, that the grain ≈øhould fall over into the heap of chaffe, and be burnt with the chaffe: So here. E≈øpecially where Satan, the great de≈øtroyer of man-kind, hath the fan in his hand: Saith Chri≈øt, Satan hath de≈øired to have you, and hath de≈øired to have you, that he may ≈øift you as wheat; and I tell you, there is ≈øo much danger in it, that nothing but my prayer can ≈øecure you, But I have prayed for you. So that you ≈øee, there is ≈øomething of a Suffering in a Temptation. You know it was a Law in the old Te≈øtament, that if a woman were abroade in the fields, and there met her ≈øome that offered violence to her; if ≈øhe cryed out, and did not con≈øent, ≈øhe was not guilty: but now, though ≈øhe were not guilty, but inocent, if ≈øhe were abu≈øed, it would be a continual affliction, to a mode≈øt good woman. So it is here, Satan comes to meet us, and though we do not con≈øent to him, yet a gracious heart cannot but look upon it as an affliction, to be thus followed,
and haunted with a Temptation. And the holy Gho≈øt alluded to this practi≈øe, when he ≈øaith here in the text, Je≈øus Chri≈øt is able to ≈øuccour: The word Succour,

In the 12. of the Revelation, it is ≈øaid, Woe to the inhabitants of the earth; for the Devil is come down with great wrath, for he knows that his time is ≈øhort. Secondly, Doth God ≈øuffer his own children thus to Suffer?

And would you know the Rea≈øon? Rea≈ø. 1 Good Authors ≈øay, That God ≈øuffers his own dear children to be tempted, that they may be more inlightened. div.head: SERMON II. Of TEMPTATION.

div.p:

God ≈øeldom does wound the head of a temptation, but fir≈øt the heel (the means) is brui≈øed whereby the head of the temptation is wounded. As Chri≈øts heel is brui≈øed in his wounding of Satans head; So I ≈øay, 'tis in regard of means: ≈øeldome that any means does wound the head of a temptation, but the very heel of that means is fir≈øt brui≈øed: and therefore, don't de≈øpi≈øe it though it be ≈ømall.

And if it plea≈øe the Lord, to ca≈øt in any Promi≈øe, when you are under a temptation: Oh! take heed, that you don't

After temptation is over, (I can but touch on things) Either you have the better of Satan: Or el≈øe the wor≈øe. If you have the wor≈øe; Be for ever Humbled, but never Di≈øcouraged. And if you have the better of him: Then rejoyce in the Lord, and in all his goodne≈øs toward you, and in all his ≈øuccouring love and mercy. Rejoyce in the Lord evermore, and again I ≈øay, rejoyce. But take heed your ≈øpirituall joy after Victory, don't degenerate into carnal joy, and you be drunk therewith. 'Tis reported of the Engli≈øh, that once going into Spain, and taking in a Town there: after they had taken it in, there being much wine in the Town, the ≈øouldiers fell a drinking of them≈øelves drunk; and the Country came down upon them, and beat them out, and recovered the Town again. So 'tis with many: They have a Victory over temptation, and they begin to rejoyce ≈øpiritually; but their ≈øpiritual joy degenerates into carnal joy, and they are drunk with their joy, and ≈øo lo≈øe their Victory. Beloved! Joy not in your Joy, but in the God of your Joy after Victory.

And if you have the better after temptation, if you have the better: be ≈øure of this, That you improve your Victory to more a≈ø≈øurance. If the Devil get the better of you, he'le be ≈øure to improve his Victory to your de≈øpair: I ≈øay, if he get the better of you, he will be ≈øure to improve his Victory to your de≈øpair. Therefore, if you get the better of him be ≈øure that you improve your Victory, to more a≈ø≈øurance of Gods love in Chri≈øt.

Yea, (my beloved) for ought I know, there is no temptation
that a child of God meets withal, but he may improve it to more a≈ø≈øurance. As thus:

Surely, If I were the Devils own, he would never trouble me thus. When the ≈øtrong man keeps the hou≈øe, all is at peace, and all is at quiet. Now ever ≈øince, from the very fir≈øt day that I have ≈øet my face towards heaven, and Chri≈øt; Oh! how have I been troubled, and tempted, and perplexed, and vexed in my ≈øpirit? Surely therefore, I am none of the Devils. Now if I had been his own, I ≈øhould have been more quiet under him: but becau≈øe I am thus troubled. And, Oh! what a good thing were it, if we did make improvement of our temptations! what gracious improvement might we make of all our temptations? and what a ble≈ø≈øed i≈ø≈øue might we have in our temptations, if we did go unto Chri≈øt for ≈øuccour.

I be≈øeech you therefore in the Lord, when as any temptation ari≈øes, go unto Je≈øus Chri≈øt, he is a ≈øuccouring Chri≈øt. To conclude, I be≈øeech you (beloved in the Lord) go to Chri≈øt and try him, put him to it: The greater your temptation is, the more fit work for Chri≈øt to cure: do not de≈øpair, do not ≈øit down; go to Je≈øus Chri≈øt, you ≈øhal find him better than I have ≈øpoken, you ≈øhall not find him wor≈øe; he will go beyond my words, he will not fall ≈øhort of my words. div.head: SERMON III. Of TEMPTATION.

epigraph.q: And the Lord ≈øaid, Simon, Simon, behold, Satan hath de≈øired to have you that he may ≈øift you as wheat: But I have prayed for thee, that thy faith fail not.

div.p:
AFTER our greate≈øt injoyments of God, u≈øually follow the greate≈øt temptations of Satan. And therefore our Saviour ≈øpeaks the≈øe words unto his Di≈øciples. In the 19. ver≈øe of this Chapter, we find them at the Lords Supper with Chri≈øt him≈øelf; This is my body which is given for you; This do in remembrance of me. Having received the Supper with Chri≈øt him≈øelf, and having had ≈øweet Communion with him there, our Saviour gives them out a mo≈øt gracious and ble≈ø≈øed promi≈øe, at the 28, 29, & 30. ver≈øes, Ye are they which have continued with me in my temptations, and I appoint to you a kingdom, as my Father hath appointed unto me: that ye may eat and drink at my table in my kingdom, and ≈øit on thrones judging the twelve tribes of I≈ørael. Having ≈øaid thus unto them; He comes in the very next words to acquaint them with a great temptation that was coming down upon them all: and therefore the≈øe words are knit together with the former by the word And; And the Lord ≈øaid, Simon, Simon, behold, Satan hath de≈øired. Though you have had this Communion with me; and though I have made
you this gracious and ble≈ø≈øed promi≈øe, know, that there is a great ≈øtorm of temptation coming down upon you.

Here are two things: The Danger of the temptation; and the Remedy again≈øt it. The Danger in the 31. and the Remedy in the 32. ver≈øe. In the 31. ver≈øe we have con≈øiderable, The Tempter; called Satan, which ≈øignifies an Adver≈øary. The Tempted; and tho≈øe are, not Simon only, but all the Di≈øciples. Satan hath de≈øiredyou: 'tis in the Plural number: he directs his ≈øpeech unto Simon, but the temptation ≈øpreads larger upon all the Di≈øciples: That he may ≈øift you.

The Lord Je≈øus Chri≈øt does give leave ≈øometimes unto Satan,
Doct.
to tempt and winnow his own and be≈øt Di≈øciples; Chri≈øts own, and be≈øt Di≈øciples are expo≈øed to Satans temptings, and winnowings: not Peter only, but James, and John, and all the beloved Di≈øciples of Je≈øus Chri≈øt were expo≈øed here unto Satans winnowings. He hath de≈øired You, in the Plural number, not thee Peter only, but you all my Di≈øciples, that he may ≈øift you as wheat.

list.item: Fir≈øt, What great power Satan hath to tempt, mole≈øt, and annoy the children of men.

div.p: Fir≈øt, Que≈øt. 1 If ye aske me, What power Satan hath to infe≈øt, mole≈øt, and thus to tempt the children of men?

I an≈øwer, An≈øw. 1 Fir≈øt, ye know that Satan is an Angel ≈øtill;
and being an Angel, he is a Superiour creature to man, and therefore, according to the rank of Creation he hath a great deal of power over man. Man hath a great power over the Bea≈øts, for man is a Superiour. The Bea≈øts have a great deal of power over the Herbs, and the gra≈ø≈øe, for the Bea≈øt is the Superiour. The Angels by Creation are Superiour to man, Satan, though fallen, is an Angel ≈øtill: according to the rank of Creation, therefore he mu≈øt needs have a mighty power over the children of men.

But he is not only a Superiour creature, An≈øw. 2 but al≈øo a more Spiritual creature than man, he is a ≈øpirit; and upon that account, he is more able to come within a man, to clo≈øe with a mans ≈øoul and ≈øpirit: being ≈øpirit him≈øelf, he is more able to conver≈øe with, to clo≈øe and get within our ≈øouls and ≈øpirits.
Thirdly, He is able to ≈øugge≈øt unto man what≈øoever he plea≈øes, and to ca≈øt in a thou≈øand ≈øinfull objects into a mans mind one after another. An≈øw. 3

Further, He is not only able to pre≈øent and ≈øugge≈øt; An≈øw. 5 but he is al≈øo able to follow his ≈øugge≈øtions. It is ≈øaid, That he ≈øtood up, and provoked David to number the people: he did not only pre≈øent that evill unto David, but he did ≈øolicite, he provoked David to number the people (≈øaies the text.)

He is not only able thus; but he is able al≈øo, An≈øw. 6 to bemire the phan≈øie, to rai≈øe ≈øtormes in that lower region: A mans ≈øoul (ye know) it works by organs, it works by the body, and by the phan≈øie: now Satan being able to di≈øturbe the phan≈øie of a man, is thereby able al≈øo, to hinder the very operation of the ≈øoul.

La≈øtly, An≈øw. 8 satan hath ≈øo great a power, that the ≈øame words that are given unto God, and unto the holy Gho≈øt for good, in Scriptnre, are given al≈øo unto Satan for evil. The holy Gho≈øt is ≈øaid to enlighten a man: Satan is ≈øaid for to blind him, The god of this world hath blinded their eyes; ≈øaies the Apo≈øtle. The Spirit is ≈øaid to Rule in us; Satan is ≈øaid, To rule in the children of di≈øobedience. The holy Cho≈øt is ≈øaid, To work in us mightily, the ≈øame word is u≈øed for Him al≈øo. The holy Gho≈øt is ≈øaid, To fill the hearts of beleevers; They were filled with the holy Gho≈øt: So are mens hearts ≈øaid, To be filled with Satan: Saies Peter to Ananias, why hath Satan filled thine heart? Indeed, there are three things e≈øpecially, wherein he does fal ≈øhort: for though Satan is able to di≈øcern what temptations would take be≈øt with a man, yet he don't know mans thoughts, for God only is the knower of ones thoughts; that is Gods prerogative. The Devil is Magnipotent (≈øaies Luther) but not Omnipotent: the Devil may be very powerful, but he is not Almighty: neither does he put forht an Almighty power in his temptations, as God does in the conver≈øion of a ≈øinner. But very powerful Satan is. In the 6. chapter to the Ephe≈øians,

For we wre≈øtle not again≈øt fle≈øh and blood, but again≈øt principalities, again≈øt powers, again≈øt the rulers of the darkne≈øs of this world, again≈øt ≈øpiritual wickdne≈øs in high places. It is ≈øomething for a man to have all the world again≈øt him, to have all man-kind again≈øt him: if all man-kind ≈øhould be agin≈øt one man, you would ≈øay, there were a great ≈øtrength; but behold more than that, here is ≈øomething more than fle≈øh and blood that every man does wre≈øtle again≈øt: For we wre≈øtle not again≈øt fle≈øh and blood: all man-kind is but fle≈øh and blood, and ≈øo ther's a weakne≈øs; but we wre≈øtle not again≈øt fle≈øh and blood, but again≈øt principalities, for Authority; and again≈øt power, for Strength; and again≈øt the rulers of the darkne≈øs of this world, and again≈øt ≈øpiritual wickedne≈øs in high places. p.hi: Whether does Satan put forth this power,

div.p: Yes, An≈øw. for they are the Saints that the Apo≈øtle ≈øpeaks of here, in that to the Ephe≈øians; For we wre≈øile not again≈øt fle≈øh and blood. You that are Ephe≈øians, and you that are Saints We wre≈øtle not again≈øt fle≈øh and blood, but again≈øt principalities and powers. Properly, ye don't wre≈øtle with a man that is down; ye wre≈øtle with a man for to throw him down; but he mu≈øt be a ≈øtanding man that ye wre≈øtle withal: ye don't wre≈øtle with one that does run away but one that ≈øtands to it. Now all wicked men, they are down, but the Saints they ≈øtand, and they labour to throw Satan down, and Satan labours to lay them all along in unbelief: but they properly do wre≈øtle with Satan, for they ≈øtand, the other are fallen already.

Yea, the Saints are not only tempted by Satan; but the
be≈øt, and the mo≈øt beloved Di≈øciples of Je≈øus Chri≈øt. In the old Te≈øtament: who more beloved than David, and Job? yet they tempted. In the new Te≈øtament, who more beloved than Peter, and Paul? One of the Circumci≈øion, and the other of the Uncircumci≈øion and Apo≈øtle≈øhip, and yet both had ≈øpecial temptations.

Yea, it is po≈ø≈øible for one of Gods own children to be ≈øo far oppre≈øt with Satan, that he may even be weary of his life. In the 10. of Job, and the 1. ver≈øe, ≈øaies Job under his great temptations: My ≈øoul is weary of my life. And if Rebekah were weary of her life, becau≈øe of the children of Heth: much more may a poor, gracious ≈øoul be weary of his life, by rea≈øon of the≈øe children of darkne≈øs, the≈øe powers of darkne≈øs, the≈øe temptations of Satan.

But you will ≈øay, Que≈øt.
Why ≈øhould Satan lie ≈øo heavy upon Gods own children and people? for he may know, that they ≈øhall be ≈øaved do he what he can: Satan had heard our Saviour Chri≈øt ≈øay to Peter, The gates of Hell ≈øhall not prevail again≈øt thee; and yet now Satan tempts: if Satan know this, why ≈øhould he follow Gods children, yea, the be≈øt of his children ≈øo ≈øorely with ≈øad temptations?

Satan is the envious man we reade of in Scripture; An≈øw. 1 and when he hears the Lord owning and honouring of his children, then does his envy work and ri≈øe: and when he hears any of Gods children triumphing by faith, and making boa≈øt of the love of God, then does his malice kindle into a flame; ≈øhall ≈øuch a one go to Heaven, and ≈øhall I be damn'd? (≈øaies he) ≈øhall ≈øuch a one be received, and ≈øhall I be ca≈øt away for ever? The≈øe are the boylings of this envious mans heart again≈øt the children of the mo≈øt high.

But there is this great rea≈øon for it. An≈øw. 2 Satan knows, that if he can but make Gods people, and the be≈øt of his children fall; though they ≈øhould not be damn'd, but pardoned, that their fall ≈øhall be ≈øtumbling blocks unto others that may be damn'd. And therefore, I pray mark, how it is carried concerning Dauid: it is ≈øaid, in the 1 Chron. 21. chapter, and the 1. ver≈øe. That, Satan ≈øtood up again≈øt I≈ørael
to provoke David to number I≈ørael. It is not ≈øaid thus, And Satan ≈øtood up again≈øt David, and provoked David to number I≈ørael: no, but thus, And Satan ≈øood up again≈øt I≈ørael, and provoked David to number the people: he ≈øtood up again≈øt I≈ørael; why? becau≈øe he know, that if he did make David thus to number the people, it would be a ≈øtumbling for all I≈ørael, and all I≈ørael ≈øhould fare the wor≈øe by it. When Satan ≈øtands up, and tempts the ma≈øter of a family unto ≈øin, he does not barely ≈øtand up again≈øt him, but in tempting him, he ≈øtands up again≈øt all the family. When Satan tempts a religious holy man, a beloved Di≈øciple of Chri≈øt in a Town, Satan ≈øtands up again≈øt all the Town in tempting that one man. He ≈øtood up again≈øt I≈ørael, and tempted David to number the people: and ≈øo when he tempts tho≈øe that are the mo≈øt beloved Di≈øciples of Chri≈øt, he ≈øtands up again≈øt others; and therefore though Satan knows, that their ≈øins ≈øhall be pardoned, yet he does follow them with ≈øad and ≈øore temptations. An≈øw. 3

Thirdly: Satan loves to divide between friends: he is the great make-bait of the world, he loves to divide. He may know, that there is ≈øo much goodne≈øs between man and wife, that he ≈øhal never part them; and yet he will labour to ≈øow di≈øcord between them, that they may live uncomfortably. And ≈øo, though he knows he ≈øhall never part Chri≈øt and a poor beleever; yet he will labour to throw jealou≈øies into the heart of a beleever concerning the love of Chri≈øt. He knew well enough what was ≈øaid concerning our Saviour Chri≈øt: What was ≈øaid by the Angels at the birth of Chri≈øt; what was ≈øaid by the Angel to Mary; what was ≈øaid by Elizabeth; he heard what was ≈øaid from Heaven, This is my beloved Son, in whom I am well plea≈øed: and yet pre≈øently he comes to Chri≈øt with an If: If thou be the Son of God: laboring to throw a jealou≈øy into the heart of Chri≈øt, and to doubt of his Son-≈øhip, even with God the Father. So I ≈øay, although Satan ≈øhould know, that the Lord will pardon ≈øuch of ≈øuch a man, yet he loves to make a divi≈øion between God and the ≈øoul, and to ca≈øt in jealu≈øies between

Chri≈øt and a beleever. As for others (≈øaies he) they are my own already, I ≈øhal not need to break into that hou≈øe, there is nothing but chaffe lies there; but here's a godly man, and here's trea≈øure; and therefore he does e≈øpecially lay his battery again≈øt the Satines, and tho≈øe that are the mo≈øt beloved Di≈øciples of Je≈øus Chri≈øt.
But you will ≈øay unto me, Que≈øt. 3 How does Satan come by this tempting power; this infe≈øting, and mole≈øting power?

Great is the power (as we have read already) that he hath as he is a Superiour creature:Au≈øw. but Satan hath yet another power, and that is the power of Conque≈øt; for in Adams fall, Satan conquered the whol world, all man-kind, they were the Devils conque≈øt upon the fall. But I ≈øay, upon the fall the Devil made a conque≈øt upon all man-kind, and ≈øo by conque≈øt he hath a great power. Satan hath heave from God the Father to tempt; I don't ≈øay, that he hath a ≈øpecial leave for every temptation, not a ≈øpecial commi≈ø≈øion, or permi≈ø≈øion, or leave for every temptation; but there is no great, or extraordinary temptation that does fall upon the children of God, but Satan hath a ≈øpecial leave from God the Father for it. There was a ≈øpecial temptation upon the Country, in his running their herd of ≈øwine into the Sea, and he had leave for that before he did it. There was a ≈øpecial temptation upon Ahab, in the lying ≈øpirit of the Prophets, and he had a ≈øpecial leave, and permi≈ø≈øion from God for that. There was a ≈øpecial temptation upon Job, and he had a leave for that. Here was a ≈øpecial temptation coming down upon the Di≈øciples, and he had leave for that. Simon, Simon, Satan hath de≈øired you. He was fain to ask leave, and he had leave for that. There is no extraordinary, or great temptation befals any of the children of God, but Satan is fain to ask leave for it: he hath a leave for it, before he can come and tmept the ≈øoul.
But you will ≈øa then unto me, Que≈øt. 4 Why does God the Father give Satan leave thus to tempt his own Children, and Chri≈øts own Di≈øciples?

Fir≈øt: take it thus, Lood what≈øoever is the end, An≈øw. 1 and the i≈ø≈øue of any evil which befals the children of God, that was the de≈øign of God the Father, in ≈øuffering that evil to come upon them. Now the end, and i≈ø≈øue of the Saints temptation is alwaies good unto them; and therefore God ≈øuffers the temptations of his people, becau≈øe he hath a de≈øign of mercy, and love upon them in the≈øe temptations. What was the end, and i≈ø≈øue of Satans tempting of Adam and Eve? They fell and then the righteou≈øne≈øs of Chri≈øt, and eternal life thereby was brought in: this was the end and the i≈ø≈øue of it. Now God the Father had this de≈øign upon Satans temptation, all the while Satan was tempting of Adam: and the Lord would never have ≈øuffered our heel to have been brui≈øed by Satans temptation, but that he did intend to break the head of Satan. It was a great temptation, that of David, when as Satan ≈øtood up, and provoked him to number the people: pray, what was the end, and i≈ø≈øue of that temptation? I ≈øhall only name the Scriptures: The 1 Chron. the 21. chapter: and the 22. chapter and the beginning of it, and the 2 Chron. the 3. chapter, and 1. ver≈øe, compared together, you ≈øhall find this: Fir≈øt Satan tempts David; he numbers the people, the people being numbered, a plague breaks forth: the plague prevailing, David goes and offers up a ≈øacrifice at the thre≈øhing flowre of Ornan; and there God told him the temple ≈øhould be built. David had a long time de≈øired to know where the Temple ≈øhould be built: he ≈øaies, he would give no re≈øt unto him≈øelf, no ≈øleep unto his eye-lids, until he had found out a place for God: you ≈øhall find, that David had this place di≈øcovered as the i≈ø≈øue of this temptation, this was the i≈ø≈øue of it, the Devil had as good have let David alone, he had as good have been quiet, for David now had the end & the i≈ø≈øue, attain'd unto that, that he never did attain unto before. So I ≈øay it is with the people of God, the Lord never ≈øuffers his own children to fall into any ≈øin, but he does intend to wean them from that ≈øin that they do fall into, even by the falling into it: the Lord never ≈øuffers any of
his own children to be tempted, but he intends to break the back of that temptation, even by their being tempted. This is the de≈øign of God the father: Oh! what a glorious de≈øign of love, and mercy is here upon all the temptations of Gods people!
But God hath yet greater, An≈øw. 2 and higher de≈øigns: The Manife≈øtation of his own Power; of his own Wi≈ødom; of his own Faithfulne≈øs; of his own Love and Free grace.

But in regard of the Saints them≈øelves: How ≈øhould they give a Probate, or Te≈øtimony of their uprightne≈øs, and ≈øincerity, their firm, and fa≈øt cleaving to God, if they were never tempted: reade for this purpo≈øe, the 13. of Deuteronomy, and the 2. and 3. ver≈øes. And ≈øo, when men can hold out, notwith≈øtanding all their temptations, they give a Te≈øtimony of their uprightne≈øs, and ≈øincerity, and that their ≈øouls do cleave unto God in truth. For the≈øe, and many other rea≈øons, the Lord doth ≈øuffer his own be≈øt, and deare≈øt Children to be tempted by Satan.

div.head: I come to Application.
div.p: If God doth ≈øuffer his own people, and deare≈øt children,Applica. to be expo≈øed to Satans temptings and winnowings: Why ≈øould any man then doubt of his Child-≈øhip, doubt of his own everla≈øting condition, and ≈øay, That he is none of the child of God becau≈øe he is tempted? Beloved! I have ≈øeen a ≈øore evil under the ≈øun, a vanity even among the Saints, and people of God: Some doubting of the ≈øoundne≈øs of their condition, and the love of God, becau≈øe they are not tempted; others doubt betau≈øe they are tempted. One ≈øaies, Oh! I am afraid I am none of the child of God, for I was never tempted, the children of God, they meet with temptations, but I was never yet buffetted, and therefore I am none of Gods child: Another on the contrary; I labour under the≈øe and the≈øe temptations, and therefore I fear that I am none of Gods child: yea, ≈øometimes the ≈øame per≈øon thus: Fir≈øt, he does not ob≈øerve his own heart, and ≈øaies he, I fear I am none of Gods child, for I never was tempted. But my beloved in the Lord, If this be true, That the Lord doth ≈øuffer his own, and be≈øt children, to be expo≈øed to Satans winnowings, and temptings; then why ≈øhould≈øt thou conclude that thou art not the child of God, becau≈øe thou art tempted? Oh! but, my temptations are ≈øuch as would make ones haire ≈øtand upright on ones head to thinke of them; ≈øometimes tempted, even to lay violent hands upon my ≈øelf: What think ye of Chri≈øt? when Satan ≈øpake unto him, and tempted him to throw him≈øelf down off the pinacle of the Temple. Oh! but, I am tempted with ≈øuch temptations that I am a≈øhamed to name, and my heart akes, and trembles when I do reflect on them, even with bla≈øphemous thoughts. What think ye of Chri≈øt? was not he tempted to bla≈øphemy? Saies the Devil to him, All this will I give thee, if thou wilt fall down and wor≈øhip me: what greater bla≈øphemy than to wor≈øhip the Devil? to make a God of the Devil him≈øelf, what greater bla≈øphemy? Oh! but, I fear, and doubt my condition, and the love of God towards me, becau≈øe my temptations are not as the temptations of Gods children, but my temptations are ≈øuch as cannot ≈øtand with grace, there is a ≈øpot, that is not the ≈øpot of Gods people: and are there not temptations, that are not the temptations of Gods people? have not wicked men their peculiar temptations, ≈øuch as does not fall upon the children of God? I am afraid that my temptations are of that rank and of that ≈øort, and therefore I fear and doubt my condition. Mark I pray, This ≈øame word Temptation may be con≈øidered two waies: Either in regard of the Formallity, or form of the temptation; or in regard of the Materiallity, or matter of the temptation.

Take now Temptation according to the propriety of the
≈øpeech and phra≈øe, and ≈øo wicked men are not ≈øaid to be tempted by Satan; by their own hearts they are, but I ≈øpeak of Satans temptations, properly the wicked are not ≈øaid to be tempted by Satan. He is ≈øaid to rule in them, in the children of di≈øobedience; and he is ≈øaid to lead them captive at his will: but if ye look into the new Te≈øtament, ye will not ordinarily find, that wicked men are ≈øaid to be tempted by Satan. A man does not tempt his wife, but when he ≈øolicites another woman, then he is ≈øaid for to tempt that woman. As the Sains are married to Chri≈øt, ≈øo wicked men, they are match't to Satan; and he is not in propriety of phra≈øe ≈øaid for to tempt them. Your men ≈øtealers, tho≈øe that ≈øteal children, they don't tempt their own children for to go with them, they naturally go with their father: but they come and tempt your children, they are other folkes children that they tempt. And ≈øo Satan, he is properly ≈øaid to tempt tho≈øe that are none of his children. A Ma≈øter don't tempt his ≈øervant, he is not ≈øaid properly to tempt his won ≈øervant to dwell with him, or to ≈øerve him; but he goes to another mans ≈øervant, and ≈øpeaks to him to come and dwell with him, and to ≈øerve him. As for wicked men, they are properly the ≈øervants of Satan; and therefore when the Devil ≈øolicites them to do that which is evill, or to dwell with him, and to conver≈øe with him, 'tis not I ≈øay in propriety of ≈øpeech a proper temptation: but for the ≈øervants of Chri≈øt, when he ≈øolicites them unto evil, then he is properly ≈øaid to tempt them. This for the form of a temptation.

But now, take a temptation in the Materiality of it, for the Matter of it, which is a ≈øolicitation to evil; and ≈øo wicked men are tempted by Satan; yea, they are more tempted than the godly are; that is, they are more ≈øolicited unto evil by Satan; and the ≈øame temptation that godly men are tempted with, wicked men are tempted with: and the ≈øame temptation that wicked men are tempted with, a godly man is tempted with. As there is no Duty which a godly man does performe, but a wicked man may do it,

But you will ≈øay unto me, Object.
This evil that is upon my heart, is not the temptation of Satan, but indeed it is the corruption of mine own heart, and therefore I fear my condition. Indeed, if I were ≈øure that it were only the temptation of Satan, I ≈øhould never que≈øtion Gods love, nor mine own condition becau≈øe of it; but, Oh! This is no new thing, An≈øw. 1 for Gods own people and children, to charge all Satans temptations upon their own hearts, to lay all at their own door. But in the Second place: An≈øw. 2 Although this be ≈øo, that it is u≈øual with the Saints thus to do, to charge all upon them≈øelves, and nothing on Satan; yet know, that the Saints ≈øeldom or never do fall into any great ≈øin, but Satan hath a ≈øpecial hand therein. For this cau≈øe, when I could no longer forbear, I ≈øent to know your faith, le≈øt by ≈øome means the tempter have tempted you, and our labour be in vain. Thirdly, Although this be true, An≈øw. 3 That there is no great ≈øin that the Saints do fall into, but Satan hath a ≈øpeciall hand in it: Yet it is the property and di≈øpo≈øition of Gods people to be humbled and grieved under their temptations as if they were all their own and nothing of Satans.
