And be ≈øure of this, if thou would≈øt prevent temptation, that ye labour more and more to walk in the light: Satan is the prince of darkne≈øs, and he walks in darkne≈øs: and he tempts in darkne≈øs. When night comes the bea≈øts go forth to their prey, ≈øaies the P≈øalmi≈øt, And when Satan ≈øees a poor ignorant ≈øoul, that walks in the dark, ≈øaies he, Here's a fit prey for me. Oh! therefore, you that are ignorant, and have ≈øate ignorant under the Ordinances; for the Lords ≈øake, labour to get more light, and more knowledge, get your heart opened unto every truth of God, labour to acquaint your ≈øelves more with Go≈øpellight, and ≈øet your bo≈øomes open unto every truth of the Lord.

And, beloved! whether you would overcome, or whather you would prevent temptation; what ever means you u≈øe; be ≈øure of this, That you take your temptation and dip it in the blood of Chri≈øt. Take a candle, that is lighted, and
only blow out the candle, the candle is ea≈øily lighted again: but when the candle is out, take it and put it into the water, and then 'tis not ≈øo ea≈øily lighted again: So now a temptation comes, and you blow it out with a Re≈øolution, and you won't yeeld to it, alas, 'tis ea≈øily lighted again: but now, take this candle, take this temptation, and come and dip it in the blood of Je≈øus Chri≈øt, and it will not be ≈øo ea≈øily lighted again; ≈øo you ≈øhall be able to prevent temptation for the time to come: Never re≈øt alone in re≈øolving, but, Oh! take your temptation and dip it in the blood of Je≈øus Chri≈øt.

And if that you do overcome your temptation at any time; be thankful to God: if ye have more than fle≈øh and blood again≈øt you, ye ≈øhall have more then fle≈øh and blood with you. And therefore, have you overcome temptation? go away and be very thankful, and ≈øay, Oh! though fle≈øh and blood be again≈øt me, yet I have more than fle≈øh and blood with me, prai≈øe the Lord much: And if you have been overcome with temptation, yet be not di≈øcouraged; for ye hear the Doctrine, God doth ≈øuffer his own dear children to be tempted, to be buffeted, to be expo≈øed to Satans temptings, and to Satans winnowings. But though ye be tempted, and it be a temptation of Satan, yet ye hear withall, That 'tis the property, and di≈øpo≈øition of Gods own people to grieve, and mourn under their temptation as if it were all their own, and nothing of Satans. Wherefore now (my beloved) having heard the≈øe things, think on them, and the Lord ble≈ø≈øe them to you every day more and more.

div.head: SERMON IV. Of TEMPTATION.

epigraph.q: And the Lord ≈øaid, Simon, Simon, behold,Preached at Stepney Oct. 17 1647. Satan hath de≈øired to have you that he may ≈øift you as wheat: But I have prayed for thee, that thy faith fail not.

div.p: YE find that the≈øe words hold forth the relation of a great ≈øtorme of temptation coming down upon Chri≈øt's Di≈øciples: The Danger of it. And the Remedy again≈øt it. Of the Danger ≈øomewhat ye heard from the 31. ver≈øe. And now I am to ≈øpeak unto the 32. ver≈øe. But I have prayed for thee, that thy faith fail not.

Here is ≈øomewhat Implied; and ≈øomwhat Expre≈øt: Implied, Satans De≈øign, and his great De≈øign upon their faith. Expre≈øt, Chri≈øts love and care, his ≈øpecial love and care over them, and towards them in this temptation. As if he ≈øhould ≈øay thus, Simon, Simon, Satan hath de≈øired to tempt you; not only thee, but all my Di≈øciples: the temptation is great, and in this temptation, his great de≈øign is upon your faith: but I have ≈øpoken unto my Father, and your Father, that your faith may not fail. So that hence you may ob≈øerve thus much: That in the time of temptation, Doct. Satans great De≈øign is upon the faith of the Saints, to make their faith fail.

He doth not ≈øay, But I have prayed for thee, that thy Prayer faile not, or that thy Patience fail not, or that thy Love fail not; but I have prayed that thy Faith fail not. So that Satans great de≈øign in all his temptations is upon the faith of the Saints, that he may make their faith to faile them.
For the further clearing, and opening of the≈øe words, and of this Truth; I ≈øhall labour to ≈øhew you.

list.item: Fir≈øt, What it is for to fail in our faith: and how far the Saints may fail in their faith in time of temptation.
Secondly, What an evilthing it is for the Saints to faile in their faith in time of temptation.
Thirdly, That Satans great de≈øign in all his temptations, is upon our faith.

Fourthly, How Satan labours to weaken our faith in the time of temptation: what ≈øtrokes he gives unto our faith, and how we ≈øhall be able to bare off tho≈øe blows in the time of temptation that ≈øo our faith fail not?

div.p: If ye aske me, Que≈øt. 1 What it is for to fail in faith here?

The word in the Original ≈øignifies, An≈øw.
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ
an Eclip≈øe, as the Eclip≈øe of the Sun, or of the Moon: and the words may be ≈øo tran≈ølated, But I have prayed for thee, that thy faith be not Eclip≈øed. But according to the ordinary acception of that word Eclip≈øe, Peters faith did fail, for it was much Eclip≈øed. The word ≈øignifies al≈øo, a total defect, ≈øuch as Judas made, who of a Di≈øciple became an Enemy, a Traitour; and in ≈øtead of beleeving, fell to de≈øpair: and ≈øo Peters faith did not faile. A mans faith is ≈øaid to faile, Either when it fals ≈øhort of what it hath been, or what it ≈øhould be; and in both the≈øe re≈øpects Peters faith did fail: It fell ≈øhort of what it had been, it fell ≈øhort of what it ≈øhould be. But there is a Two fold failing in faith: One in regard of the Acting and Exerci≈øe of faith; and another in regard of the grace of faith it ≈øelf. In regard of the Acting, Working, and Exerci≈øe of faith, Peters faith did fail: but in regard of the grace it ≈øelf, ≈øo it failed not. The Lutherans, they ≈øay and contend much for it, That a regenerate mans faith
may fail totally, and finally in time of temptation: and ≈øo they ≈øay, that Peters faith failed here, when he denied his Lord and Ma≈øter; becau≈øe it is ≈øaid in the next words, When thou art converted, ≈øtrengthen thy brethren. As if his faith had failed ≈øo far, as he ≈øhould need a new conver≈øion. But that word tran≈ølated, When thou art converted, (as divers of the learned do well ob≈øerve) may be tran≈ølated,
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ
Again, thus: I have prayed for thee that thy faith fail not: and do thou ≈øtrengthen thy brethren again: do thou return to that work again. And ≈øo you have the ≈øame word u≈øed in the Septuagint, tran≈ølated in the 58. P≈øalm, at the 6. ver≈øe. Wilt thou not revive us again? The word in the Hebrew is thus: Wilt thou not convert, or turn unto us, and revive us? which we tran≈ølate, Wilt thou not revive us again? And ≈øo the words here may be tran≈ølated, (being an Hebrai≈øme) But do thou ≈øtrengthen thy brethren again. But ≈øuppo≈øe that the words ≈øtand according to their pre≈øent tran≈ølation, it does not argue, that Peter did fail totally in this temptation: for, the whole life of a Chri≈øtian here, is a continual converting, and turning to God: We repent, and repent again; turn, and we turn again. Every day we turn unto God yet more and more; every day brings forth another conver≈øion: yet not ≈øo, as if the former conver≈øion were made void. And if the faith of a beleever would fail totally in the time of a temptation; what ≈øhould be the meaning of tho≈øe words, in the 1. of Joh. 5. Chapter, and the 18. ver≈øe. We know, that who≈øoever is born of God ≈øins not; but he that is begotten of God, keepeth him≈øelf, and that wicked one toucheth him not: The wicked one: that is Satan, he toucheth him not. But now, if Satan could tempt a godly man, and prevail ≈øo far in his temptation, as to make his faith fail totally, then he would touch him to the purpo≈øe: but (≈øaies the text) he keeps him≈øelf, and the wicked one toucheth him not: and therefore his faith cannot fail totally, a regenerate mans faith cannot fail totally. And ye know what is ≈øaid, in that 7. of Matthew at the 24. and 25. ver≈øes. Who≈øoever heareth the≈øe ≈øayings of mine, and doth
them, I will liken him unto a wi≈øe man, which hath built his hou≈øe upon a rock; and the rain de≈øcended, and the flouds came, and the winds blew and beat upon that hou≈øe; and it fell not, becau≈øe it was founded upon a rock. Now every Beleever is founded upon a rock, (Chri≈øt) and therefore, though the rain de≈øcend, and the flouds come, and the winds blow, and temptations be never ≈øo great, he cannot fail totally, becau≈øe he is built upon a rock. In the 13. of Matthew, ye know it is made the property of the fal≈øe ground, that in the time of temptation it fell away: Now if the good ground (a regenerate man) ≈øhould fall away in the time of temptation; what difference were there between the fal≈øe ground, & the good ground? Plainly therefore, the Scripture holds forth this truth unto us, That a regenerate man, a Beleever, though his faith may fail much, yet it does not fail totally in time of temptation. And thus Peters faith failed, and thus it failed not: In regard of the Exerci≈øe, and Acting of his faith, it did fail; but in regard of the grace it ≈øelf, faith it ≈øelf, ≈øo it failed not: and ≈øo it is, and may be with others of the Saints al≈øo.
Secondly: Que≈øt. 2 If the faith of a beleever do only fail in regard of the Acting, Exerci≈øe, and Working thereof, What great inconvenience is there, or evil in the failing of his faith?

Much, (my beloved) very much: An≈øw. For though that faith fail only in regard of the Acting, Exerci≈øe, and working, he does lo≈øe an opportunity of glorifying God. 'Tis ≈øaid of Abraham, That he beleeved, and gave glory to God. Faith gives glory to God: it glorifies his Power, his Mercy, his Faithfulne≈øs, and his Wi≈ødom; not faith in the Habit, but faith in the Exerci≈øe of it glorifies God: and ≈øo much as a mans faith doth fail, in the Acting, Working, and Exerci≈øe of it, ≈øo much he lo≈øeth an opportunity of glorifying God.

Moreover, He lo≈øes his own Comfort. Faith is a Comforting grace. Being ju≈øtified by faith, we have peace with God. And in the 15. to the Romans, and the 13. ver≈øe, ye find, That Joy and Peace grows upon faith: Now the God of hope,
fill ye with all Joy and Peace in beleeving. So much as a man does beleeve, ≈øo much Joy and Peace: if a man fail in the Exerci≈øe of his faith, he does lo≈øe his Comfort.

Yea, hereby al≈øo, he does lo≈øe his pre≈øent prize. A Chri≈øtan hath a prize in this life; he hath a two-fold crown: A crown of glory in the world to come; and a pre≈øent crown. And therefore ≈øaies the Lord unto the Church of Philadelphia, Hold fa≈øt that which thou ha≈øt, le≈øt another take thy crown. Now if a man do fail in the Exerci≈øe of his faith, he does lo≈øe much of his pre≈øent prize. Ye know how it was with Mo≈øes and Aron, ye reade of it in the 20. chapter of Numbers, and the 12. ver≈øe. And the Lord ≈øpake unto Mo≈øes and Aaron, Becau≈øe ye beleeve me not, to ≈øanctifie me in the eyes of the children of I≈ørael; therefore ye ≈øhall not bring this congregation into the land which I have promi≈øed them. They were ≈øhut out of the land of Canaan for not beleeving. But Mo≈øes & Araon did not lo≈øe the grace of faith, it was only failing in the Exerci≈øe of faith; their failing was not in the grace it ≈øelf, but only they failed, in the Exerci≈øe of their faith, and they were ≈øhut out of Canaan for it. And Mo≈øes be≈øought the Lord earne≈øtly in prayer, that he would rever≈øe this threatning, and it might not be; he was ≈øhut out of Canaan, meerly for failing in the Exerci≈øe of his faith. Oh! what an evil thing is it then, for a Chri≈øtian to fail in his faith, though it be no more than in the Exerci≈øe of his faith.

Further, In this failing of ones faith, though but in the Exerci≈øe of it; A Chri≈øtian does lo≈øe much of the benefit, and ≈øweetne≈øs of the mercy promi≈øed. Look as it is with a wicked man, in regard of the judgment threatned; So with a godly man in regard of the mercy promi≈øed. Now take a wicked man, and let the threatning of God be fulfilled before him upon others, upon him≈øelf; he profits not by Gods judgments. Why? becau≈øe that he don't exerci≈øe faith concerning the threatning; and ≈øo when the judgment comes, he profits not by Gods dealing, by Gods judgments, he lo≈øes the benefit of Gods di≈øpen≈øations that way. So I ≈øay with a godly man: let the promi≈øe be fulfilled, and po≈ø≈øibly
he does not find the ≈øweetne≈øs, or the benefit of the mercy promi≈øed when the promi≈øe is fulfilled: Why? becau≈øe he don't exerci≈øe faith in the promi≈øe it ≈øelf. When as the Lord gave Manna, Mo≈øes had the ≈øeetne≈øs of it, why? becau≈øe he exerci≈øed faith about it: But the children of I≈ørael, they make a tu≈øh of it, a light matter of it: why? becau≈øe they look't upon it in a way of ≈øence, & did not take it in a way of beleeving, and ≈øo they lo≈øt the benefit, and ≈øweetne≈øs of the mercy promi≈øed. Beloved! it is no ≈ømall matter this, for to lo≈øe the benefit, and ≈øweetne≈ø≈øe of the mercy promi≈øed: that a Chri≈øtian lo≈øes by failing in his faith in regard of the Exerci≈øe of it; and therefore certainly it is a very evil thing: though their faith fail not in regard of the grace it ≈øelf, yet if it fail in regard of the work, and the exerci≈øe of it, it is a very evil thing, and much inconvenience comes unto the Saints thereby.
Thirdly, Que≈øt. 3 Whereby may it appear, that Satans great de≈øign is upon our faith in the time of temptation?

He does tempt mo≈øt unto that ≈øin which is the greate≈øi: and the ≈øin again≈øt the Go≈øpel is the greate≈øt ≈øin. An≈øw. Satans great de≈øign is, to hinder the work of Chri≈øt, the kingdom of Chri≈øt in the hearts of the Saint; to counter-work the Spirit of God. Satan does tempt that he may tempt: and the greate≈øt temptation u≈øually comes in the reare, comes at the la≈øt. Satan does tempt a man to break the Law; but he hath a further reach in that: for he tempts a man to break the Law, that ≈øo he may tempt him afterwards to ≈øin again≈øt the Go≈øpel: he lies in ambu≈øh in one temptation, for to draw to another. When Satan tempted our fir≈øt parents Adam and Eve, he tempted like a ≈øerpent, in form of a ≈øerpent: and ≈øo now too, he comes, and he winds about us in his temptation; but his ≈øting is in the taile, and at the latter end. And thus ye ≈øee it was in the temptation of our Saviour Chri≈øt: his great de≈øign was upon Chri≈øts faith: in the 4. of mathhew, ye know he hath Three temptations there: and ≈øaies he, in the two fir≈øt temptations, If thou be the Son of God? and If thou be the Son of God?
And in the La≈øt temptation: All this will I give thee, if thou wilt fall down and wor≈øhip me. He tempted him to Bla≈øphemy, and Athei≈øme; and what greater unbeleef? So 'tis with the Saints al≈øo: Satan, he comes and tempts them to ≈øowrene≈ø≈øe, frowardne≈ø≈øe, and pa≈ø≈øion in their families, but he hath a further reach upon that di≈øtemper: for (≈øaies he) I will tempt this man or woman to pa≈ø≈øion, and frowardne≈øs, and when he hath been froward, and pa≈ø≈øionate, then I will tempt him to be doubting whether he be the child of God or no: fir≈øt I wil tempt this man for to break the Law, and when he hath broken the Law, then will Itempt him to ≈øin again≈øt the Go≈øpel, then will I ≈øtrike at his faith: his great de≈øign ≈øtill is upon your faith in all his temptations.

But you will ≈øay, Que≈øt.
Why is Satans great de≈øign upon our faith in time of temptation?

He is the great Robber, or Theef: and if he can, An≈øw. he will be ≈øure to ≈øpoil a man of that wich is the be≈øt. Now faith is more precious than gold; the trial of your faith is, faith is the gift of God: and therefore, if he can get any thing from a man, he will get that which is Gods gift. He is the great hinderer of all good, of every good work; and he will e≈øpecially labour to hinder that work which is The work of God in a ≈øpecial manner: and this is THE Work of God, that ye beleeve in his Son. Satan knows, that faith is the mo≈øt Beneficial grace unto the Saints: The Shield of faith, it is called; and the Anchor of faith. If ye be in a ≈øtorm at ≈øea; faith is your Anchor: If ye be in danger at land, before Enemies, faith is your Shield. If that a mans Faith fail, his Duties fail, his heart failes, and all failes. He knows well enough, that he ≈øhall ≈øoon make us ≈øuffer ≈øhipwrack, if he can but weaken faith, and therefore his great de≈øign is upon our faith. He knows, that faith is mo≈øt prejudicial to Him≈øelf: for by faith we overcome the world; whom re≈øi≈øt, ≈øtedfa≈øt in the faith; And by faith we quench the fiery darts of the Devil. Now then (≈øaies Satan) Does faith quench my fiery darts? then will I labour to
quench faith if I can. The Devil does labour alwaies to pre≈øent him≈øelfe in Chri≈øts cloathes unto a ≈øoul, as an Angel of light: and he does labout to rpe≈øent Chri≈øt in his own cloathes, as an Angel of darkne≈øs. When as he is a lyar Him≈øelf, he does labour to make the ≈øoul put the lye upon Chri≈øt, and upon the Spirit. The Spirit of God, that comes and te≈øtifies unto a man or woman, Thou art the child of God: Satan ≈øaies, No. When a man therefore does ≈øay, He is not the child of God; the language of his action is, He gives the lye unto the Spirit, and he ≈øaies, that Satan ≈øpeaks true: So here he makes Chri≈øt and the Spirit of Chrhi≈øt a lyar by his unbelief; & he makes the devil to ≈øpeak true. Now this is Satans great de≈øign, and therefore, in all his temptations, ≈øtill he ≈øtrikes at the faith of the Saints, labours to weaken their faith; his great de≈øign is upon their faith.
In the Fourth place, Que≈øt. 4 How does Satan weaken our faith in time of temptation? What are tho≈øe ≈øtrokes that Satan gives unto our faith? and how ≈øhall we be able to bare them off?

In the general, An≈øw. Satan does ≈øometimes labour to weaken our faith, By drawing us from the means of faith. Take the wood away from the fire, it will ≈øoon lo≈øe it's heat, if not put out. And if a man be but drawn away from the means of faith; the means drawn from him, or he from the means by his own default, his faith will be ≈øoon weakened. This Satan labours to do ≈øometimes.

Sometimes again, He rai≈øes up Mountains of Difficulties, and Di≈øcouragements in the way of a Chri≈øtians obedience; and ≈øo labours to wound his faith. Throw water upon the fire it will ≈øoon be out.
But that I may ≈øpeak the more fully unto this great Que≈øtion, the an≈øwer whereof is of concernment every day among≈øt you.

Ye know there the Three acts of faith: There is the faith of Reliance; whereby a ≈øoul does relye upon God in Chri≈øt. There is the faith of A≈ø≈øurance; Whereby a man is per≈øwaded of Gods love towards him, and his love to God,
and that he is the child of God, And there is the faith of Acknowledgment; whereby a man does own, and acknowledge the Cau≈øe, and Truth of Chri≈øt. I ≈øhall now ≈øpend ≈øome time, and ≈øhew ye, How Satan ≈øtrikes at all the≈øe faiths: and withal labour to ≈øhew you, How we may bare off his blows, that ≈øo we may ≈øtand in the time of temptation, and our faith may not fail.

Fir≈øt, For the faith of Reliance: Satan does ≈øometimes ≈øtrike at the faith of Reliance in the Saints, by hiding from them their former Experiences of Gods gracious dealing with them. So long as a man hath the ≈øight, and view of his Experiences of Gods gracious dealing with him before, he does relye on God, and he ≈øaies, I will for ever re≈øt upon God, and relye upon God in Chri≈øt, for thus and thus he hath dealt wth me heretofore. Now therfore, Satan does labour in the time of temptation, to hide the Experiences of the Saints from them, and ≈øo does ≈øtrike at their faith, and labours to make their faith faile.

But then, How ≈øhould we bare off this blow?
Que≈øt.

Thus, Take heed that ye never re≈øt upon the promi≈øe barely,
An≈øw. 1 or only becau≈øe of your Experience; but rather deal with your Experience becau≈øe of the promi≈øe. It is a good thing for a man to come up to the Promi≈øe by the ladder of Experience: but it's better for a man to go down to the promi≈øe by his Experience. And if ye look into the 106. P≈øalm, ye ≈øhall find, that when a man does re≈øt upon the Promi≈øe, barely by rea≈øon of his Experience, his faith will ≈øoon fail. The waters covered their enemies (at the 11. ver≈øe, 'tis ≈øpoken of the I≈øraelites when they came through the red ≈øea) there was not one of them left. Ver≈øe the 12. Then beleeved they his words. (Mark) now becau≈øe of their Experience, now they beleeved Gods word, now they beleeved his promi≈øe by rea≈øon of their Experience; Then beleeved they his words, they ≈øang his prai≈øe. But what became of this? Reade the next words: They ≈øoon forgate his works, they waited not for his coun≈øel. So that I ≈øay, take heed that ye don't re≈øt upon the promi≈øe barely, and only becau≈øe of your Experience, for if your
Experience be but out of the way a little, then your heart will fail, and your faith fail pre≈øently.

Take heed that ye never mourn for any evil,
An≈øw. 2 no not for ≈øin it ≈øelf, ≈øo as to be unthankful for, or unmindful of former mercies. We are very apt to this; and Satan he comes and tempts, and ≈øaies unto a poor ≈øoul, Are you ≈øpeaking of former mercies, or ble≈ø≈øings to be thanful for them? That is a good work for others, but as for you, you have committed ≈øuch a ≈øin, and it's your duty now to mourn for your ≈øin committed, look you to that, to be humbled; apply your ≈øelf to that work: and ≈øo when he hath gotten a mans heart fix't upon that work in oppo≈øition to thankfulne≈øs for former mercies received, the ≈øoul lo≈øes the ≈øight of his Experience and ≈øo his faith failes in the time of temptation. Wherefore my Exhortation is, that you may avoid this blow, and this ≈øtroke, Never mourn, no not for ≈øon committed; but ≈øtill be thankful for grace received, otherwaies your Experience will go out of ≈øight, and then your faith failes ye.

Again, An≈øw. 3 Satan does ≈øometimes ≈øtrike at the faith of Reliance, Labours to weaken the faith of the Saints Reliance, By ≈øundering or ≈øevering their ≈øouls from the promi≈øe. So long as a man hath the ≈øight of the promi≈øe, and the promi≈øe is by him; a gracious heart ≈øaies, I wil for ever tru≈øt in God, and relye upon God in Chri≈øt, for thus and thus hath God ≈øpoken, and thus and thus ≈øaith the promi≈øe to me. But now, if the promi≈øe be gone, then a mans reliance fails. Satan therefore, in the into of temptation, labours to take away the promi≈øe; ≈øcaring the ≈øoul, or cogging the ≈øoul from the promi≈øe; this he does many waies, but ≈øometimes he ≈øpeaks out thus: What! do you meddle with the promi≈øe? the promi≈øe don't belong to you, the Threatening belongs to you; you have finned ≈øo and ≈øo, and the Threatning belongs to you, but the Promi≈øe don't belong to you: And if he can but get the ≈øoul to beleeve this, then his faith failes.

Oh! Que≈øt. but, How ≈øhould we bear off this blow in time of temptation? for I confe≈ø≈øe thus, by this temptation does Satan ≈øtrike at
my faith, and labours to make my faith to faile.
In this ca≈øe, let a mans heart ≈øpeak thus: An≈øw.

Fir≈øt: If the Lord do command me to beleeve,
then the promi≈øe belongs to me, for I cannot beleeve unle≈øs I apply the promi≈øe: now in this time, at this very time of my temptation, the Lord does command me to beleeve, el≈øe it were no ≈øin not to beleeve; 'tis a ≈øin for me not to beleeve, not therefore the Lord commands me to beleeve; but beleeve I cannot unle≈øs I apply the promi≈øe, therefore God would have me to apply the promi≈øe, therefore the promi≈øe does belong to me, and I may apply it.

Again, Let the heart ≈øpeak thus: If the Lord does give out a Threatning that it may not be fulfilled; and he does give out a Promi≈øe that it may be fulfilled: If the very applying of the Threatning, makes the Threatning not to belong to me; and the very applying of the Promi≈øe, makes the Promi≈øe to belong to me; then the Threatning does not belong to me, for I have applied it; and the Promi≈øe does belong to me, for I have applied it; Oh! I remember how my ≈øoul hath lien trembling before the Threatning, the Lord knows I have often applied the Threatning: but now this is true, That the very applying of the threatning, makes the threatning not to belong to a man; and the very applying of the Promi≈øe, makes the Promi≈øe to belong to a man; and therfore Satan, the Threatning belongs not unto me, but the Promi≈øe does.

But then again Thirdly, let him ≈øay thus: If I be more godly now, than I was when Satan told me, that the Threatning did not belong to me; and the Promi≈øe did belong to me, then there is no rea≈øon for this temptation. When I went on in a way of ≈øin, then Satan told me, the Threatning did not belong to me; and then he told me, the Promi≈øe did belong to me: Oh! but now I am more godly than I was then, I have more of Chri≈øt than I had then I am ≈øure, & therfore Satan, Did≈øt thou tel me, that the Promi≈øe did belong to me then? 'therefore it belongs much more to me now. Thon told≈øt me heretofore, when I went on in a way of ≈øin, the Threatning
did not belong to me: now then the Threatning does le≈øs belong to me, for now I am more godly than I was then.

But above all things, remember that of the Commamnd to beleeve. Luther was a man that laboured under great temptations: and being once ≈øorely tempted, and the teares trickling down his cheeks; ≈øaies he my friend (my ≈øpiritual father) came unto me, and ≈øaid, O my ≈øon! why doe≈øt thou mourne? doe≈øt thou not know that God hath commanded thee to beleeve? When (≈øaies Luther) I heard that word, Command, that God hath Commanded me to beleeve; it prevail'd more with my heart, than all that was ≈øaid, or thought on before. So ≈øay I now unto ye, Does Satan come with this temptation, and tell thee, the Promi≈øe don't belong to thee? An≈øwer, I but the Lord hath Commanded me to beleeve (Satan) God hath Commanded me to beleeve, 'tis my duty now at this time to beleeve; but I cannot beleeve unle≈ø≈øe I apply the Promi≈øe, therefore I may go by commi≈ø≈øion from God unto the Promi≈øe, and the Promi≈øe does belong to me. Thus, give in the≈øe an≈øwers, ≈øo ≈øhall ye be able to ≈øtand, and to relye upon God, and your faith of Reliance ≈øhall not fail. This is the fir≈øt thing, The faith of Reliance.
Secondly, Que≈øt. 2 How does Satan ≈øtrike, or labour to weaken the faith of A≈ø≈øurance, the A≈ø≈øurance of Gods people?
Much may be ≈øaid here, An≈øw. 'tis a large field I ≈øhall only gather up ≈øome few things, and pre≈øent them to you.

Sometimes Satan does labour to weaken the A≈ø≈øurance of the Saints, By telling them that they have no faith. A≈ø≈øurance is the flower of faith, it grows upon faith; but you have no faith (≈øaies Satan) and therefore your a≈ø≈øurance is naught. But how unrea≈øonable is this temptation! for, ob≈øerve I pray, in what rounds Satan goes: He tempts us to beleeve that we have no faith, becau≈øe we have no A≈ø≈øurance; and he tempts us again, to beleeve we have no A≈ø≈øurance, becau≈øe we have no faith. For an≈øwer hereunto, I ≈øhall only turn unto that 4. to the Romans: It is ≈øaid of Abraham
(at the 21. ver≈øe) Being fully per≈øwaded, that what God had promi≈øed, he was able al≈øo to perform. And therefore (at the 22.) it was imputed to him for righteou≈øne≈øs. Now it was not written for his ≈øake alone, that it was imputed to him: but for us al≈øo to whom it ≈øhall be imputed, if we beleeve on him that rai≈øed up Je≈øus our Lord from the dead. Abraham was ju≈øtified by faith, it was imputed to him for righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe: and ≈øaies the Apo≈øtle here, it was not written for his ≈øake, but for us al≈øo. We are ju≈øti≈øied as Abraham was, by the ≈øame faith, what faith is that? is it the faith of A≈ø≈øurance? Yes! he was A≈ø≈øured indeed, but I pray of what? He was A≈ø≈øured that God was able to performe: He being fully per≈øwaded, that what he had promi≈øed, he was able al≈øo to perform. Abraham beleeved that God was able, and ≈øo relyed upon God, and hereby he was ju≈øtified. So it ≈øhall be with men and women now: if they be A≈ø≈øured, and Per≈øwaded, that God is able, and ≈øo relye upon God; this is the faith that ju≈øtifies. When therefore this temptation comes, An≈øwer unto Satan: Satan, thou ≈øaie≈øt I have no A≈ø≈øurance, becau≈øe I have no faith; but I have this A≈ø≈øurance that Abraham had, whereby he was ju≈øtified, I beleeve God is able to help me, and ≈øo I relye upon God, and therefore (Satan) I am now ju≈øtified, and ≈øtand righteous through Je≈øus Chri≈øt in the ≈øight of God.

Secondly, As he does labour to weaken the faith of A≈ø≈øurance, By telling the Saints that they have no faith: So al≈øo, by telling them, That they have no Obedience, that they don't profit under the means, that they are not fruitfull: where ever there is true faith, there will be Obedienee, and men will profit under the means, and be fruitful; but you are Unfruitful, and you are barren, and where's your Obedience? here's no Obedience, therefore no faith: So no A≈ø≈øurance, your A≈ø≈øurance is wrong.

Well, But how may we ward,
Que≈øt.
and keep off this blow in the time of temptation, that our faith of A≈ø≈øurance may not faile?

Truly, this blow is not to be warded off, An≈øw. if this be true;
That ye never were Obedient, never Fruitful, never profited by the means of grace; this blow fals dead upon the ≈øoul, this blow is not to be warded off, this is no temptation. But now, if ye have ever been fruitful, if ye have ever been obedient, if ye have ever profited by the means of grace; though for the pre≈øent ye may ≈øeem dead: yet remember what Job ≈øaies, There is hope of a tree, though it be cut down, that by the ≈øcent of waters it will flori≈øh again. And ≈øo, there is hope of thy ≈øoul, that by the ≈øcent of the Go≈øpel-waters thou maie≈øt flouri≈øh again. But though there be no obedience in your own eye, though ye don't profit under the means in your own eye; yet your obedience may be in the eye of others: and in time of temptation, another mans eye is a better judge than your own.

But ≈øuppo≈øe there ≈øeem to be no obedience, neither in your own, nor anothers eye; yet the root of the matter may be in you. Ye know how it is with the fi≈øh, that are in the water, in a windy and a ≈øtormy day: ye put many fi≈øh into a pond; and in a faire, ≈øun ≈øhiney day, ye ≈øee them playing upon the water, upon the uppermo≈øt part of the water; but in a rainy, and ≈øtormy day, ye ≈øee none of them there, but yet you ≈øay, they are all there, they are in the water, they are at the bottome, though you ≈øee them not. And ≈øo, it may be, in this ≈øtormy time of temptation, your obedience, and profiting is not ≈øeen, but it may be there as heretofore. Satan does never more pre≈ø≈øe a child of God, to try him≈øelf by ≈øigns of grace drawn from his own conver≈øation, than in the time of temptation. There is indeed a good u≈øe of ≈øigns drawn from our own conver≈øation, but this is agreed upon by all, That there's no u≈øe of them in the time of temptation. And therefore ≈øaies Luther: In the time of temptation, I am as if there were no Law, nor no works, but only the righteou≈øne≈øs of Chri≈øt in the world, and ≈øo I do re≈øt uphim. Does Satan come forth therefore with this temptation, That you have no obedience, that you don't profit, that you are Unfruitful? An≈øwer it thus: True Satan, I confe≈ø≈øe I am very Unprofitable, and therefore I will learn to
profit more; I confe≈ø≈øe I am very unfruitful, and therefore I will labour to be more fruitful: But (Satan) I will not now at this time determine about my Condition; for it may be a time of temptation: hereafter, at another time, I will come and determine about my Condition, and I will look after ≈øignes; but now at this time, it may be a time of temptation, and therefore I will forbear to winde, and draw up a conclu≈øion, but leane my ≈øelf upon God, and re≈øt upon God at this time.

Thirdly, Sometimes Satan does labour to weaken the A≈ø≈øurance of Gods people, the faith of A≈ø≈øurance, to make that to fail, By telling of them, that they have no faith at all, becau≈øe they have no particular faith, no particular promi≈øe; for, ≈øaies Satan thus: faith and Wavering, faith and Doubting do not agree; He that beleeveth doubteth not: but now, you pray and doubt, you beleeve and waver, ye have no particular word for what you beleeve, therefore ye have no particular faith, ≈øo no faith at all, and therefore your A≈ø≈øurance is naught.

p.hi: How ≈øhould we ward off this blow?

div.p: An≈øw. In this ca≈øe now, let a poor beleever ≈øay Two or Three things unto his own ≈øoul.

Fir≈øt, Tell thy ≈øoul this: Though it plea≈øes God ≈øometimes to give out a particular word unto his people, a particular promi≈øe, in the time of Affliction, or De≈øertion (e≈øpecially) or temptation; yet the Lord does not therefore giveout a particular promi≈øe, that a man may mea≈øure his condition thereby; (there's a mi≈øtake) but the Lord does therefore give out a particular word or promi≈øe, to uphold the ≈øoul in the condition: not to mea≈øure out his condition by it, but to uphold him; and therefore, though I have not a particular word, or promi≈øe, I will not conclude again≈øt my faith for this.

Again, Tell thine own ≈øoul, That though it plea≈øes the Lord to give out a particular word or promi≈øe ≈øometimes; yet alwaies he does not. Hezekiah had a particular word for his recovery; but the three children had not a particular
word, that they ≈øhould be delivered out of the fiery furnace, yet they beleeved; and whether God deliver, or does not deliver, (≈øay they) we will not bow our ≈øelves to this Idolatry. So that, though God is plea≈øed ≈øometimes, to give out a particular word or promi≈øe, yet alwaies he does not, and therefore my faith may be right (Satan) though I have not a particular word now for this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe.

Again, Tell thy ≈øoul this: That though God is plea≈øed thus to indulge, and ≈øometimes to give out a particular promi≈øe unto his people, and they have a particular faith concerning this or that bu≈øine≈ø≈øe; yet there is alwaies a Waiting-faith that we reade of in Scripture. There is a faith of Recumbency, whereby a ≈øoul leans upon God, and commits his cau≈øe unto God: And there is a Waiting faith. Now therefore (Satan) though I have not a particular word, and a particular faith for this bu≈øine≈øs; yet notwith≈øtanding I have a Waiting faith, I can waite upon the Lord my God, and I can re≈øt upon Je≈øus Chri≈øt: and therefore (Satan) I do yet beleeve, and my faith is right. Tell your own ≈øoul thus; ≈øo ≈øhall you be able to ≈øtand to your faith, and ≈øhall not fall off in the time of your temptation.

Thirdly, For the faith of Acknowledgement. Sometimes Satan does labour to weaken the faith of the Saints Acknowledgement. He does labour either that they ≈øhould deny the Truth, or not own it: either that they ≈øhould deny Chri≈øt, or that they ≈øhould not own him. So he laboured to make Peters faith to fail, by denying Chri≈øt. And therefore, he comes unto a poor ≈øoul and ≈øaies, If you will go on in this way, it ≈øhall co≈øt you a pri≈øon; can you lie, and rot, and die in a pri≈øon? he rattles chaines in the ears of a poor beleever, and ≈øo labours to ≈øcare him away from his con≈øcience, and from his faith, and from the Truth and Cau≈øe of God, and the good waies of Chri≈øt.

p.hi: How ≈øhold we ward off this blow?

div.p:
Fir≈øt, An≈øw. 1 Before the temptaton comes, labour to po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe your heart much, with the Mercy, and priviledge of ≈øuffering
for the Cau≈øe, Truth, Name, and Way of Chri≈øt. To you it is given, not only to beleeve, but to ≈øuffer; 'tis a great Gift: A ≈øuffering opportunity, and a ≈øuffering heart, is a great Gift from God. Is it not a great mercy to be conformable to Je≈øus Chri≈øt our head? For this Cau≈øe (≈øaies Chri≈øt) came I into the world, that I might bear witne≈øs unto the truth, Is it not a great mercy, to be confe≈ø≈øed at the la≈øt day before all the world, Angels, and men? He that confe≈ø≈øes me before men, (≈øaies Chri≈øt) Him will I confe≈øs before my father &c. Is it not a great mercy, to live and reigne with Chri≈øt a thou≈øand years? ye know that Scripture; I ≈øhall not ≈øpeak of the meaning of it now, but cerainly, there is a great deal of glory promi≈øed there, living and reigning with Chri≈øt a thou≈øand years: and the promi≈øe is made unto tho≈øe that do acknowledge, and own the Cau≈øe, and Truth of God and Je≈øus Chri≈øt. Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe your heart much, with the priviledge, and mercy of bearing witne≈øs to the Truth, the Cau≈øe, and the good way of Chri≈øt before your temptation comes.

Secondly, An≈øw. 2 If you would bear off the blow of this temptation; Be ≈øure that you look upon both ≈øides of your ≈øuffering, or bearing witne≈øs to the Truth, Cau≈øe, or way of Chri≈øt: the Dark ≈øide, and the Light ≈øide; let them not be ≈øundered. When the Lord cals for any of his people to ≈øuffer at any time for him, he does give them more ≈øtrength than before, and he does give them more Comfort and Con≈øolation than they had before. Now Satan, comes and holds forth the ≈øuffering, he makes mention of the ≈øuffering; but he hides the Strength, and the Con≈øolation. Either Satan holds forth the ≈øuffering alone; or el≈øe, if he do mention any ≈øtrength, or comfort that a gracious ≈øoul ≈øhall have in the ≈øuffering, 'tis but the ≈øame ≈øtrength that he hath now, he don't ≈øpeak of the ≈øtrength he ≈øhall have then, and the great Con≈øolation that he ≈øhall have then when the ≈øuffering comes: and ≈øo the≈øe being parted, the Suffering and the Con≈øolation being parted, now our faith fails. When ever therefore this temptation does
come upon you, an≈øwer thus: Satan, here thou bringe≈øt the ≈øuffering before me, and cau≈øe≈øt that to come before me; but thou doe≈øt not tell me of the ≈øtrength I ≈øhall have, and of the con≈øolation I ≈øhal receive Satan, I ≈øhall not have the ≈øtrength I have now, nor the con≈øolation I have now, but I ≈øhall have more ≈øtrength then, when the ≈øuffering comes, and I ≈øhall have more con≈øolation, when as the affliction comes than I had before. Keep the≈øe together, don't look only upon the one ≈øide of your ≈øuffering, and witne≈øs-bearing; but look upon both ≈øides together, and thus you ≈øhall be able to ≈øtand, and ride out the ≈øtorm of this temptation.

But you will ≈øay, Que≈øt. We have heard of the ≈øeveral blowes that Satan gives unto our faith: unto the faith of Reliance, unto the faith of A≈ø≈øurance, and unto the faith of Acknowledgment; how he labours to weaken all the≈øe our faiths, and how we ≈øhould bear off al the≈øe blows: But there may be yet ≈øome temptation (po≈ø≈øibly) that does not fall within the compa≈øs of the≈øe temptations: the≈øe directions are pointed again≈øt the≈øe particular temptations; but I have other temptations that don't fall within the compa≈øs of the≈øe, whereby Satan labours to weaken my faith, and to make my faith to fail: What general Rules and Directions may be given, by which a man ≈øhould ≈øo walk, as that Satan may not make his faith to fail in the time of his temptation?

Fir≈øt: An≈øw. 1 Before your temptation comes, while you are upon even ground; Study, and look much into the Scripture, and into every corner, and nook thereof, (as I may ≈øo ≈øpeak) laying, and trea≈øuring up Promi≈øes, and Words ≈øutable to every condition. Let the Word of the Lord dwell in you richly; that ≈øo when a temptation comes, ye may have a word ≈øutable at hand, and this will help ye to bear off the ≈øtrength of the temptation when it comes.

Secondly. An≈øw. 2 Either a particular Word and Promi≈øe does come unt ye, or it does not, in the time of your temptation. If it do come unto ye, Take heed that ye dont' mea≈øure your ≈øelves, or your condition, by the warmth, and life, and inlargment of
your heart which ye have at the coming in of the word. And if a particular word, or Scripture, and promi≈øe do not come unto you in the time of your temptation; don't mea≈øure your ≈øelves, and your condition, by the ≈øtraightne≈øs, and deadne≈ø≈øe of your heart which you have at that time when a particular word does not come.

Thirdly, If temptaion come, An≈øw. 3 Look much unto the infirmities of Je≈øus Chri≈øt: not the ≈øinful infirmities, for ≈øo he had none, but he had many other infirmities. And ye know what the Spou≈øe in the time of De≈øertion ≈øaies, in the book of the Canticles, His left hand is under my head, and with his right hand he does imbrace me. The right hand, is a hand of power; and the left hand, is a hand of weakne≈ø≈øe: and in the time of De≈øertion, and Temptation, it's a great relief to a poor ≈øoul, to con≈øider the infirmities of Je≈øus Chri≈øt, his left hand is under our head then. As when a man is inlarged in heart, 'tis good to con≈øider of Chri≈øts Example, that ≈øo he may be humbled under his inlargement: So when a man is in De≈øertion, or Temptation, it's good for to think of Chri≈øts Infirmities, that ≈øo he may not be overwhelmed, or ca≈øt down too much.

Fourthly, If temptation do come, be ≈øure of this, An≈øw. 4 That ye don't conclude it is no temptation. Satan tempts, and then he tempts a man to think it is no temptation. So long as a poor ≈øoul thinks it is but a temptation, his heart is borne up with comfort, and he ≈øaies, It is but a temptation, and it will be over ≈øhortly, and the Lord Je≈øus Chri≈øt will pity me, for 'tis but a temptation, and ≈øo his heart is borne up with comfort, waiting upon God: But if the Devil can get a man ≈øo far, as to make him think it is no temptation, but wor≈øe than a temptation; then his heart fails, and his faith failes. Therefore, I be≈øeech ye, If a temptation come, don't conclude it is no temptation, but ≈øay, Oh! it may be 'tis a temptation, and therefore I will wait on God.

Fifthly, If temptation come, An≈øw. 5 Remember thine own ≈øoul of the waies of God with thee. Gods waies (ye know) are in the
deep, and his foot≈øteps are not known: but as the Heavens are greater than the earth, ≈øo are Gods waies of mercy beyond our waies. Now therefore, if a drak temptation do come upon ye, and ye ≈øee no way to get out, ≈øay, O but my ≈øoul, remember Gods waies are infinite, and his waies are beyond our waies; and though I ≈øee no way, God hath infinite waies, he walks over mulbery-trees, and his waies have been in the deep; and ≈øo it hath been all along with my ≈øoul, and therefore now, O my ≈øoul, wait on God.

Sixthly, An≈øw. 6 If temptation come, if Satan come, Do you run to Chri≈øt; and look how Satan appears to you, ≈øo do you apply the Attributes of Chri≈øt to you ≈øutable to his temptation. Does Satan ≈øet a temptation unto your brea≈øt? ob≈øerve what temptation it is, and take an Attribute of Chri≈øt ≈øutable to that temptation, and ≈øet it to the brea≈øt of that temptation. For Example: Does Satan come and tempt as a Serpent? Then remember, that Je≈øus Chri≈øt is the bra≈øen ≈øerpent. Does Satan come and pre≈øent him≈øelf as a roaring Lyon? Now remember, that Je≈øus Chri≈øt is the Lyon of the tribe of Judah. Does Satan come and pre≈øent him≈øelf as an Accu≈øer? Now remember, that the Lord Je≈øus Chri≈øt is an advocate. Beloved! in the time of temptation, ye are to run to Chri≈øt, that is true; but that is not all, but you are to ob≈øerve how your temptation lies, and apply that Attribute of Chri≈øt to your ≈øoul which is ≈øutable to your temptation: do this, and your faith ≈øhall not faile in time of temptation.

Seventhly, An≈øw. 7 and la≈øtly. Above all things, take the Shield of faith. Take the Shield of faith, that your faith may not fail: for, the way to beleeve is to beleeve; the way to pray is to pray; the way to hear, is to hear; the way to receive, is to receive; the way to perform duty, is to perform duty; the way to exerci≈øe grace, is to exerci≈øe grace. When temptation therefore does come upon thee, that thy faith may not fail, now ≈øtir up thy ≈øelf to this work of faith, and to beleeve; and if ye beleeve that ye ≈øhall overcome, ye ≈øhall overcome; and if ye beleeve that ye ≈øhall prevaile again≈øt
your temptations, ye ≈øhall prevaile again≈øt your temptations. And, poor ≈øoul, if thou can≈øt relie upon Chri≈øt, and beleeve that thou ≈øhalt be ju≈øtified, thou ≈øhalt be ju≈øtified; and if thou can≈øt by faith relie upon the Promi≈øe, the Promi≈øe ≈øhall belong to thee. Wherefore, ≈øtir up your ≈øelves now to beleeve when temptation comes. When ye have to deal with an Enemy here among men, I don't ≈øay, beleeve ye ≈øhall overcome your enemy, and ye ≈øhall overcome: a man may beleeve he ≈øhal overcome his outward enemy here in the field, and yet fall before him, and not overcome: but having to deal with this enemy, Gods enemy, your fathers enemy, and your enemy; beleeve ye ≈øhall overcome him, and ye ≈øhall overcome him.

Que≈øt.
But ≈øhall we overcome him Only if we beleeve?

An≈øw. Who ever thou art that ≈øpeake≈øt, or thinke≈øt thus: Doe≈øt thou make on Only of beleeving? I tell thee from the Lord, It is an harder thing to beleeve, than to keep all the Commandements: for there is ≈øomething in Nature towards the keeping of the ten Commandements; but nothing in Nature towards beleeving in Chri≈øt. And, (poor ≈øoul) doe≈øt thou make an Only of beleeving? thou doe≈øt not know what beleeving means: but I ≈øay unto thee from the Lord, Beleeve that thou ≈øhalt overcome, and thou ≈øhalt overcome; beleeve that thou ≈øhalt prevaile again≈øt Satan, and thou ≈øhalt prevail again≈øt him; beleeve that thy ≈øins ≈øhal be pardoned through Chri≈øt and relie upon him, and thy ≈øins ≈øhal be pardoned. When≈øoever therefore any temptation comes, Oh! run to Chri≈øt, cry unto Chri≈øt, and re≈øt upon Chri≈øt, and ≈øay, Lord I do beleeve, help thou my unbelief.

Beloved in the Lord, ye have heard, That in all Satans temptations, his great de≈øign is upon your faith, to weaken your faith: therefore, let it be all your de≈øign, in all your temptations, to ≈øtrengthen your faith, and to look to your faith. Which that ye may do, think on all the≈øe things, and the Lord ble≈øs them to you.

div.head: SERMON V. Of TEMPTATION.

epigraph.q: And the Lord ≈øaid, Simon, Simon, behold, Satan hath de≈øired to have you that he may ≈øift you as wheat:Preached at Stepney Oct. 24 1647. But I have prayed for thee, that thy faith fail not.

div.p: THe≈øe words (as ye have heard) acquaints us with a great temptation that was to come down upon Chri≈øts Di≈øciples. Concerning which ye have here, The Danger of the temptation: And the Remedy again≈øt it. For the Danger of the temptation, I have ≈øpoken already: and now come unto this 32. ver≈øe, But I have prayed for thee, that thy faith fail not. Here is ≈øomething Implyed; and ≈øomthing Expre≈øt. Satans de≈øign implyed, which is, and was, to weaken the faith of Chri≈øts Di≈øciples, to make their faith to fail. And of that ye have heard already.

Now that which is expre≈øt is; Chri≈øts tender care of, and love unto his Di≈øciples in regard of their temptations. div.p: For An≈øwer, An≈øw. 1 Fir≈øt, There is a great deal of difference between the failing of your Faith, and the failing of your Heart. But yet further, Who≈øoever you are, that ≈øay your faith fails you, and therefore you are afraid that Chri≈øt prayes not for you: Man or woman, Did thy faith ever fail thee like Peters; did≈øt thou ever deny thy Lord and Ma≈øter as Peter did? and yet Chri≈øt ≈øaid, I have prayed that thy faith fail not, and he was heard in the thing that he prayed for.

Oh! Object. but yet (will ≈øome ≈øay) I have ≈øinned greatly, very much; I have been a great ≈øinner; and therefore I fear, that the Lord Je≈øus Chri≈øt will let me alone to wre≈øtle with my temptations all alone, and will not pray and intercede for me in the time and hour of my temptation.
